The person finished might transfer minced garlic to a hot pan, into a bowl, or wipe the board and prepare to sauté or season.

chopping_tomato.progress_description: Start: a whole tomato on a cutting board; smooth glossy red skin, green calyx visible, roughly fist-sized. In progress: tomato halved or quartered; pale interior with exposed seed pockets and jelly; seeds glisten; remaining skin forms round disks or irregular wedges; pieces vary in thickness; juice on the board. The person uses a chef’s grip on the knife, stabilizes with tucked fingertips, and makes deliberate slicing or chopping motions, occasionally repositioning pieces as they work.
chopping_tomato.finished_description: End state: tomato fully chopped into uniform pieces (diced/minced), typically small cubes about 0.5–1 cm. Skin intact, flesh bright red with pale seeds/pulp visible. Consistency ranges from firm yet yielding to slightly juicy; no whole tomatoes or large chunks remain; minimal liquid on the board. The person finished might be lifting the chopped pieces into a bowl or skillet, wiping the knife/board, or starting sautéing or sauce prep.

chopping_apple.progress_description: During chopping, the apple shows partial segmentation: skin intact in some areas, exposed pale flesh in cut faces. Surfaces can be jagged or smooth depending on blade angle. Pieces range from thin slivers to irregular chunks; core may be partly exposed with seeds visible. Juices bead on surface; the fruit remains firm-crisp with slight browning on the cut faces. Color varies with variety (red, green, or yellow skin). The knife is mid-stroke or resting on a cut plane; one hand stabilizes the apple while the other guides the knife. Peel fragments and droplets may be scattered on the board.
chopping_apple.finished_description: End state: apple pieces are uniformly cut (1–2 cm dice or bite-sized wedges). Flesh is pale white to cream; skin shows red, green, or yellow. Surfaces are crisp and juicy with slight moisture; cross-sections display intact cells. Browning is minimized if treated (e.g., lemon juice). Core may be removed or contained. Presentation on a cutting board or in a bowl, ready for cooking or salad. The worker might be scooping pieces into a bowl, transferring to a pan, or tossing with lemon juice and other ingredients to prevent browning.

chopping_parsley.progress_description: Parsley on a cutting board, stems and leaves largely intact. In progress, the knife engages the bunch, producing uneven cuts: some leaves and stems are bisected, others torn, yielding a mix of long shreds and small chunks. Edges appear ragged; moisture and gloss on fresh green surfaces, with darker tones near cuts and lighter green on intact parts. Loose clippings pile as the person gathers sections, rotates the herb, and maintains a steady chopping or rocking motion, occasionally lifting and reorienting the bundle.
chopping_parsley.finished_description: End state: a neat heap of uniformly minced parsley; pieces about 2–3 mm, leafy fragments with stems trimmed; bright green with even distribution; texture light and airy, not wet or mushy, with no large chunks; loose, powdery flecks present. The person finished might be sprinkling it over a dish, transferring to a small bowl, or wiping the board and washing the knife.

chopping_carrot.progress_description:
Start state: Whole carrot, bright orange and tapered; skin intact with dirt specks, optional light peeling; flesh firm with a pale core visible when peeled.
 
In-progress state: Knife at work; stabilizing hand in a claw grip. Partial cuts produce uneven segments—some pieces still attached, others separated along the shaft; cross-sections show pale, fibrous interior; edges range from clean to jagged; thickness varies; tiny moisture beads on fresh surfaces.
chopping_carrot.finished_description: End state: uniformly cut carrot pieces ready for cooking or serving. Common forms are batons (about 5 mm thick, 2–3 cm long) or dices (roughly 5–8 mm). Each piece has clean, straight cuts; surface is smooth; color is bright orange and consistent; no brown spots or peel fragments; edges are crisp and firm. Pieces are evenly sized for even cooking. The person finishing may transfer to a bowl or tray, wipe the knife, or move ingredients to a pan, oven, or salad prep.

chopping_pepper.progress_description: Pepper is in mixed prepped state: whole peppers, halves, or large slices with some smaller fragments. Skin is glossy red/green/yellow; interior flesh pale, crisp, and slightly fibrous. Seeds may cling to halves. Edges show rough or clean cuts; chunks vary from wide strips to irregular dice. A knife is mid-slice or resting; the person stabilizes with one hand while applying downward pressure or rotating the pepper, creating uneven, transitional pieces on the board.
chopping_pepper.finished_description: End state: pepper pieces are uniformly sized and shaped (e.g., small dice ~5 mm or thin julienne), seeds removed, skin intact and glossy, flesh moist but not wet, with no stems or core fragments. Colors stay bright red/green/yellow per pepper. The cutting board is mostly clean, with a few remaining bits; pieces are either in a prep bowl or in a pan, ready to cook. The person finished might be transferring the chopped pepper to a bowl or skillet, then wiping the board or cleaning the knife.

chopping_mushroom.progress_description: Start or in-progress states: Whole mushrooms with smooth white-to-tan caps and pale, firm stems. Cap tops may be domed; edges may have a few dirt flecks. In progress, the mushroom sits on a cutting board with a knife in action. Partial cuts yield exposed pale cross-sections and irregular thickness; some pieces still cling to the stem or to neighboring pieces. Knife marks are visible, edges jagged or clean, moisture gleaming on the surface. The person’s grip is steady, one hand stabilizing, the other guiding the blade, employing a slicing or rocking motion.
chopping_mushroom.finished_description: End state: uniformly cut mushrooms in consistent pieces ready for cooking. Dice about 4–6 mm, or slices 2–3 mm thick; surfaces freshly cut with pale interior and lightly darker exterior caps. Color ranges white to light tan; moisture present but not pooling; no large uncut chunks; stems trimmed flush. Texture is firm and uniform. The person may transfer the pieces to a bowl or pan, wipe the board, and proceed to sauté, add to a sauce, or incorporate into a dish.

chopping_bacon.progress_description: Starting and intermediate states show a raw bacon block on a cutting board. The piece is pink meat with white fat marbling, initially a uniform rectangle. As progress continues, portions become partially separated into strips or irregular chunks; cross-sections reveal exposed pale pink surfaces and slick fat, with jagged or uneven edges. Pieces vary in thickness from slim to chunky; some slices remain attached to the slab or rind. The person holds a knife at an angle, guiding, sawing or lifting, with fingers tucked away and offcuts scattered nearby.
chopping_bacon.finished_description: End state: chopped bacon consists of irregular cubes and short strips, mostly 5–10 mm across, with a mix of pink meat and white fat. Surfaces are moist, edges jagged, pieces sometimes clump. Color hues range from pale pink to deeper pink; marbling visible. The pile on a cutting board resembles a loose heap, not intact slices. After finishing, the person might transfer pieces to a pan or bowl, wipe the board, and prepare to cook or season, possibly rinsing or cleaning the knife.

chopping_cilantro.progress_description: Start/intermediate state: A bunch of cilantro with glossy green leaves and pale stems sits on the board. As chopping begins, leaves loosen from stems; the knife makes short, rhythmic scoops and pivots. Fragments range from irregular ribbons to small, uneven specks; some pieces retain blade-edge marks, others appear torn. The pile shows mixed sizes and uneven color—brighter leaf shards against duller midribs. Moisture beads on leaves; fingers hold stems at the base, the other hand guiding the knife through the pile, mid-motion.
chopping_cilantro.finished_description: End state: cilantro finely minced into uniform 1–3 mm pieces; leaves and tender stems chopped evenly with no large stems or stringy bits. Color is bright green with pale flecks; texture moist but not soggy, forming a loose pile on the cutting board or in a prep bowl. No clumps; pieces well distributed. The task is done, and the person is typically sweeping the board with a spatula to transfer the cilantro to a container or pan, or wiping the knife/board clean.

chopping_spinach.progress_description: Start or intermediate chopping states show spinach on a cutting board in transition: whole leaves with stems mixed with torn pieces. Leaves range from dark to bright green; surfaces are damp and glossy from washing, sometimes wilted. Pieces vary from large ribbons and irregular chunks to coarse shreds, with veins visible. The knife is mid-chop or mid-pull, blade contacting a piece or lifted, hands guiding the cut. The pile is uneven and scattered, with damp clumps and stray stems, indicating ongoing processing.
chopping_spinach.finished_description:
End state: uniform chopped spinach—either chiffonade ribbons about 1–3 mm wide or small diced bits 2–6 mm; dark emerald color, slightly glossy; tender, moist surface; stems removed; pieces well separated, not mashed or clumped.
 
Next action: the person may transfer the chopped greens to a bowl or skillet, then wilt them over heat or incorporate them into a recipe.

chopping_cabbage.progress_description: Starting state: whole cabbage head with tight, green leaves; core visible, outer leaves intact. In-progress state: cabbage partially disassembled—cut into large wedges or rough slabs; some pieces still attached to the core while others lie on the board in irregular shapes. Colors range from glossy green outer leaves to pale white inner layers; moisture beads on surface; edges show fresh knife scoring. Pieces vary in size from coarse chunks (~2–4 cm) to thin ribbons (~2–5 mm). The handler’s hands stabilize the board, fingers tucked, maintaining a safe grip while guiding the knife in short strokes.
chopping_cabbage.finished_description: End state: cabbage is uniformly cut into small pieces, either fine shreds (about 1–3 mm ribbons) or small cubes (2–5 mm). Color pale green to white; crisp, moist, with no torn leaves or large stems. Surfaces smooth, pieces evenly sized, loosely piled on a board or in a bowl. The task is complete; the person may be wiping the knife, sweeping scraps, and transferring chopped cabbage to a container for cooking or storage.

chopping_nut.progress_description: Start state: whole nuts—hard shells or intact kernels; shapes round to oblong; colors brown to tan; surfaces smooth to matte. In-progress/intermediate states: irregular fragments from half-shell to shards and coarse particles; sizes range from a few millimeters to fine grains; textures from hard to crumbly, with shell dust. In-action cues: knife or chopper mid-stroke, rocking or slicing on a board, shells cracked, pieces scattered; the person grips the handle, applies pressure, and pauses between chops.
chopping_nut.finished_description: End state: Nuts are irregular bite-sized fragments rather than whole pieces. Coarse chop yields roughly 2–6 mm pieces; fine chop yields 0.5–2 mm granules. Colors match the variety (tan to brown); surface dry and slightly glossy from natural oil; texture crisp, crumbly, not sticky. No large shards or intact halves. The person finished may be sprinkling the chopped nuts over a dish, folding them into batter, or transferring them to a bowl, while wiping the knife.

chopping_banana.progress_description: Starting/intermediate state: a ripe banana with skin intact or partially peeled. A knife is pressed into or resting on the fruit, making partial cuts and visible grooves along the length. The skin is yellow with brown speckles; the exposed flesh is pale cream, firm yet yielding, moist at the cut edge. Edges and surfaces show uneven remnants and unevenly sized material where not yet separated. The person stabilizes the banana on a board with one hand and guides the blade with the other, advancing the cut without finishing it.
chopping_banana.finished_description: End state: peeled banana fully chopped into uniform pieces. Shapes: coins (3–5 mm thick) or small cubes (≈0.5–1 cm). Size should be consistent. Color: pale yellow interior with brown speckles on ripe fruit; exterior flesh creamy and soft. Texture ranges from firm to mushy depending on ripeness. Resulting pile neat and evenly spread on a cutting board or in a bowl, with no large uncut portions. The person might be transferring pieces to a bowl or pan, washing the knife, or cleaning the workspace.

chopping_strawberry.progress_description: At start, berries lie intact on a cutting board, some with stems. Red skins are glossy; exposed flesh is pale pink to white where cuts begin. The knife is mid-swing or paused, yielding half-elliptical cross-sections or irregular fragments. Surfaces are moist and glossy, with seeds and occasional juice. Sizes vary: whole berries, halves, and uneven fragments. The pile looks mixed in shape and thickness, with juice streaks on the board. The cutter's fingers hover, guiding the blade through the chop.
chopping_strawberry.finished_description: End state: strawberries are fully chopped into uniform pieces—typically small cubes (roughly 3–6 mm) or evenly sized slices, depending on the cut. Color is bright red on the outside with pale red to pink interior; seeds visible; surfaces show knife marks; no stems or leaves; minor juice on the cutting board. Texture is firm yet juicy. When finished, the person is likely transferring the chopped berries to a bowl or mixing with other ingredients, and may be wiping the knife/board or continuing prep (yogurt, salad, pastry, etc.).

chopping_cucumber.progress_description: On a cutting board, a whole cucumber with dark green skin and crisp pale green flesh sits in the early stage. As chopping proceeds, it is partially cut: some length remains intact while portions show rough cross-sections or partial baton shapes. Edges are irregular, some slices thinner than others; surface is moist with small droplets. The knife is mid-slice or resting; fingers adopt a protective claw, guiding the blade. Pieces may be attached or loosely separated, showing ongoing fragmentation.
chopping_cucumber.finished_description:
End state: cucumber is cut into uniform pieces (dice about 5–8 mm or rounds), skin on or peeled per technique; skin dark green, flesh pale green with visible seeds; surfaces cleanly cut, crisp and juicy; no large chunks; pieces spread or piled neatly on the board or into a bowl.

After finishing: the person might transfer the chopped cucumber to a bowl or salad, wipe the knife, or clear/clean the cutting area.

chopping_chocolate.progress_description: Starting state: a solid chocolate block or bar on a cutting board; color matches cocoa type, surface glossy and unbroken. In progress: a knife pierces or drags through, leaving parallel or jagged cut lines; some pieces remain attached, while others are already separated into slabs, shards, or crumbs. Shapes vary from large rectangles to irregular chunks; edges are rough, with exposed cocoa butter sheen. The block may crumble slightly under pressure, giving a powdery dust on the blade and board. The person steadies the block with one hand and guides the blade with the other, pausing as needed.
chopping_chocolate.finished_description: End state: chocolate is partitioned into uniform pieces with clean, straight-cut edges. Shapes are cubes or chips, typically 5–12 mm on an edge, with some irregular shards. Color reflects the type (dark, milk, or white) and surfaces may show a light cocoa dusting. Texture is brittle; pieces snap cleanly. They should be arranged in a tray or bowl with minimal crumbs. The worker is likely transferring pieces to a container, wiping the board, or starting to melt them.

chopping_rosemary.progress_description: Start/in-progress states: Whole rosemary sprigs with woody gray-green stems and needle leaves. In progress: knife tips along stems; leaves partly detached or still clinging; loose needles scattered on the board; uneven cuts and split stems; pieces range from torn fragments to partially shortened pieces. Colors: dark green needles, pale-green to brown stems; leaves look taut and glossy; some dampness from washing. The person is twisting, pressing, and rocking the knife, lifting and regrouping sprigs, collecting scraps on the board or blade.
chopping_rosemary.finished_description: End state: finely minced rosemary leaves in small, uniform pieces about 1–2 mm; stems removed; color bright green with darker flecks; slightly damp, with a granular, crumbly texture rather than fibrous; no whole needles or long stems visible; evenly distributed in a loose pile or sprinkled on a surface, ready to add to a dish. The person finished might be transferring the chopped herb to a bowl or pan, sprinkling into a sauce or dish, and wiping the board/knife clean.

chopping_chive.progress_description: Chives begin as long, slender, hollow green tubes with pale bases. In progress, the board shows intact stalks and partially cut pieces. Chopped bits are bright-green fragments, a few millimeters to about a centimeter long, with flat ends and knife marks. Some strands remain uncut, others are unevenly sliced; the knife is in motion, guiding the greens into a scattered pile.
chopping_chive.finished_description: End state: chopped chives appear as uniform green fragments, about 2–4 mm long, slender and cylindrical with clean ends. Color ranges bright emerald to light green; surface may be slightly glossy from moisture. No long pieces or woody stems; pieces may be evenly scattered or gathered in a small mound ready to sprinkle. The person finished might be garnishing a dish (sprinkling over soup, eggs, potatoes) or folding into a sauce, and may then sweep the board or transfer the pile.

chopping_shallot.progress_description: Start state: unpeeled shallot bulb with papery brown skin; once peeled, pale ivory cloves layered around a core. In incomplete states, you’ll see an assortment of shapes and sizes on the board: diagonal slices, irregular chunks, and some half-peeled fragments. Surfaces are moist and glossy from released juices, with color ranging from off-white to faint purple edges or mottling. Edges are jagged; some pieces are still connected to root or skin. The person grips a chef's knife in a claw grip, making chopping motions, pausing between cuts, and regrouping pieces as they go.
chopping_shallot.finished_description: End state: peeled shallots are uniformly chopped into either fine mince (roughly 0.5–2 mm pieces) or small dice (2–3 mm cubes). Color is pale ivory with purple speckles; pieces are translucent and evenly sized, with minimal moisture pooling. No large shards or uncut sections. What the person might be doing next: transferring to a bowl or directly into a hot pan with oil, stirring to sauté, and then cleaning the knife and board.

chopping_peanut.progress_description:
Start/initial: Whole kernels or shelled halves, about 1–2 cm, light tan to brown skin, smooth/oily surface; intact or slightly conical shape.
In progress: Broken fragments, irregular chunks, thin slivers, or coarse crumbs; colors from pale beige interior to roasted brown edges; cut surfaces or jagged fractures; dusty skin fragments.
What the person is doing: Gripping a knife or cleaver, applying downward force, tapping pieces, stabilizing with the other hand or palm, regrouping/rotating pieces, and scooping collected bits.
chopping_peanut.finished_description: End state: chopped peanut pieces collected or spread on a cutting board or in a bowl. Shapes are irregular fragments and slivers, with some crumbly dust. Size ranges from fine bits (~1–2 mm) to coarse chunks (~5–8 mm). Color: light tan to medium brown with roast specks; skins may remain or be removed. Surface dry and slightly glossy from oil. No whole peanuts or large halves left. The person may be transferring chopped nuts to a container, measuring portions, or wiping the board/knife clean.

chopping_vegetable.progress_description: An intermediate chopping state shows a board with intact vegetables, partial cuts, and irregular fragments. Pieces vary from thick slabs or sticks to small shards and uneven cubes; some edges are rounded, others jagged. Colors peek through skins—greens, oranges, purples—while interiors appear pale or moist. Knife marks sheen the surface; cut ends reveal varying textures. The cook’s hands guide the blade: one holds the veg in a claw, the other drives a slicing or rocking motion. Debris and scraps clutter the board, and pieces remain varied in size and shape.
chopping_vegetable.finished_description: Uniformly chopped vegetables arranged in a bowl or tray. Shapes: small dice (≈2–4 mm), brunoise, julienne, or slices. Sizes consistent for even cooking; edges clean and sharp; color bright; surfaces show slight moisture, no bruising. The pile is organized and ready for cooking. The person finished might be transferring pieces to a pan, weighing portions, or starting to sauté, simmer, or plate.

chopping_herb.progress_description:
State at start: whole leaves and stems, bright green, glossy. 
In progress: torn fragments, thin ribbons, chunky chips; uneven edges; pale, moist surfaces from washing. 
Sizes vary: shards, strips, small bits; stems partially cut. 
Action cues: knife slicing or paused mid-motion; pieces loosely gathered or scattered on the board; fresh-cut marks and dampness visible.
chopping_herb.finished_description: End state: uniformly chopped herb pieces, small and even in size (fine mince ~1–3 mm or chop ~3–5 mm). Leaf fragments bright green, minimal stems, slightly glossy from moisture, with no large chunks. Texture tender, evenly sized, not stringy. The herb is evenly distributed on the cutting board or transferred to a bowl/pan. The person finished may sweep the board, scrape into a dish, or sprinkle over food as garnish, possibly wiping the knife or board.

chopping_kale.progress_description: On a cutting board, kale is mid-cut: some leaves whole or torn, others in various cut forms. Shapes include large flat pieces, ribbons, and irregular chunks; edges show knife lines and jagged margins. Colors range from deep green to bluish-green with purple veins; surfaces are damp and glossy. Some stems may be partially removed. Pieces vary from fine shreds (few mm) to coarse bits. The knife is in motion, hands guiding a pile, stacking, gathering, and re-positioning for further slicing.
chopping_kale.finished_description: End state: kale finely chopped into uniform 3–6 mm pieces; stems removed or minced; leaves emerald-green with slightly darker edges. Pieces are evenly sized; no long shreds or visible rib. Surface is moist but not mushy; crisp-tender texture. Pile sits neatly in a bowl, ready to be massaged with oil/lemon, added to a salad, or sautéed. The person finishing this task might be transferring to a bowl, drying the board, or starting to massage the kale.

chopping_celery.progress_description: In early or intermediate frames, celery stalks are green with pale, exposed interiors. Whole stalks or partially trimmed, with leaves at one end. Cuts are uneven: some long segments intact; others partially sliced into ribbons or crosswise pieces. Cut surfaces appear white-green, moist, and fibrous, with visible strings and slight gloss. Edges may be jagged or clean depending on knife motion. The knife may hover, press, or slice through, while the hand guides the stalks against the board; some pieces are still joined, others separate.
chopping_celery.finished_description: End state: trimmed celery stalks cut into uniform, bite-sized pieces—either 5–8 mm cubes or short diagonal batons about 1–2 cm long. Color is bright green with pale interior; edges are clean and straight, surfaces crisp, moist, and dry to the touch, with no ragged fibers. Pieces are evenly sized and free of strings. The person finished might be placing chopped celery into a bowl or container, or spacing pieces on a tray, possibly rinsing, or prepping for cooking or garnish.

chopping_mint.progress_description: Start: mint bunches with leaves and stems on a cutting board; leaves bright green with darker veins, some dew, crisp texture. In progress: knife chops or tears, creating irregular fragments; pieces range from a few millimeters to about a centimeter, including torn leaf bits and narrow ribbons; edges are jagged, surfaces moist and glossy, some stems still attached; a loose pile gathers, with uneven sizes and knife-mark chatter. The person holds the blade, making rhythmic up-and-down or rocking motions.
chopping_mint.finished_description: End state: finely chopped mint leaves in uniform 1–3 mm pieces; no stems or large fragments; color bright emerald green with a slightly glossy, moist surface; aroma fresh and mentholated. The pile appears as small green flecks ready to sprinkle over dishes or fold into sauces; texture crumbly yet cohesive enough to hold shape on a spoon. The person finished might be wiping the knife, transferring the mint to a prep bowl, or turning to garnish a dish and clean up the cutting area.

chopping_dill.progress_description:
Start/intermediate states of dill chopping (in-progress cues):
 Uncut bunch on a cutting board; thick stems, feathery leaflets attached; leaves bright green, slightly translucent when wet.
 Knife poised or mid-contact; blade edge partly through stems; motion blur indicates chopping or rocking action.
 Scattered pieces: fragmented leaflets and torn stems; some long ribbons, some small slivers; pieces vary in width.
 Surface shows damp, glossy texture; small green specks nearby; board with shallow score marks.
 Hands guiding knife, fingers curled away, stabilizing the bunch.
chopping_dill.finished_description: End state: dill is finely chopped into small, uniform fragments about 2–4 mm long, with bright green, feathery leaves. Pieces are evenly distributed, not clumped, with no thick stems or long strips; the mix is fluffy and slightly damp from washing, and fragrant. The appearance is a loose pile or sprinkle rather than a paste. The person finished may be transferring or measuring the dill, sprinkling it over a dish, mixing into a sauce, or placing it in a prep bowl, knife wiped, board clean.

chopping_mango.progress_description: Start state: whole mango, waxy skin, palm-sized, flesh yields slightly to pressure, color varies (green-yellow-orange, with blush). In-progress: peeling underway; mango halved to expose the flat seed seam; knife makes parallel cuts into the flesh, creating shallow score marks; the surface is glossy orange, with visible fibrous strands; juice beads on the blade and cutting board; one hand steadies the fruit, the other moves the knife along the flesh; seed cavity and skin edges visible.
chopping_mango.finished_description: End state: mango flesh fully separated from skin and pit, cut into uniform cubes (roughly 1–2 cm) or batons, depending on method. Pieces are bright golden-yellow to orange, glossy, with smooth, clean edges; no rind or fibrous bits; consistent, bite-sized chunks; board cleared of fruit residue aside from a few stray fragments. Juices may be gathered in a container. The person finished might be scooping pieces into a bowl, transferring to a dish, or wiping the knife and board, ready to wash up.

chopping_chicken.progress_description: Start state: whole chicken or bone-in pieces with skin intact; flesh pale pink, fat white, surface moist, bone ends not exposed. In-progress: knife in mid-stroke, partial cuts create irregular chunks and strips; some portions still attached to larger mass; edges jagged, surfaces slick with moisture; color ranges from pale pink to white with translucent areas near cartilage; skin may be loosened or partially removed. The handler stabilizes the piece with one hand, guiding the blade and applying downward force while rotating the piece as needed.
chopping_chicken.finished_description: End state: chicken pieces uniformly diced or cut into bite-sized chunks (roughly 1–2 cm) or strips, with consistent size and shape. Color depends on stage: raw chicken shows pale pink, moist, slightly translucent surfaces; cooked chicken is opaque white. Texture should be firm yet tender, with no stringy fibers. No bones, and minimal large fat pockets or moisture pooling. The pieces are evenly shaped, ready for seasoning, pan-searing, or recipe assembly. The worker might be transferring to a pan or bowl, marinating, weighing portions, or prepping for stir-fry.

chopping_walnut.progress_description: At the start, walnuts may be whole on a cutting board or shelled kernels awaiting processing. In progress, you’ll see a mix of large chunks, halves, and irregular shards; some kernel pieces remain attached to half-shell fragments. The knife or grinder sits mid-action; the board is speckled with small shell fragments and dust. Colors span pale beige interiors to darker brown skins; surfaces show natural oil and a rough, jagged texture on cut edges. This stage captures ongoing fragmentation with uneven sizes and no uniform pieces yet.
chopping_walnut.finished_description: End state: chopped walnuts are small irregular pieces, about 1–5 mm, with finer crumbs. Color ranges from light tan to medium brown; skins may be visible. Surfaces are dry with a slight oily sheen. No whole halves or shells remain, and pieces are evenly distributed if machine-minced; texture is crisp and crumbly. Next actions: transfer to a mixing bowl or pan, toast briefly to deepen flavor, or fold into batter or a topping, then wipe the board and knife.

chopping_leaf.progress_description:
Start: intact leaf on a cutting board; 5–7 cm long; vibrant green; smooth surface; prominent midrib; petiole attached.
In progress: knife angled; blade touching leaf; partial incisions visible; edges uneven; small sap beads; slight curling under pressure.
Handling: dominant hand guiding knife; other hand stabilizes near base; motion rapid; slight motion blur.
State: leaf still connected at base; some areas uncut; multiple passes anticipated; components not fully separated.
chopping_leaf.finished_description: End state: finely chopped leaf matter, with no intact leaves. Fragments are irregular and small (roughly 2–5 mm), green with pale cut edges. Texture ranges from moist to slightly crumbly; stems largely removed. Pieces appear evenly distributed rather than whole blades, sometimes with fine shreds or dust in the bowl. The person finished might be scooping the chopped leaves into a container, wiping the knife, and preparing to rinse or add the prep to a dish.

chopping_potato.progress_description:
Start state: Whole potato with brown skin, oval shape, dirt on surface.
Intermediate state: Skin partly peeled; potato cut into halves, thick slices, and irregular chunks; pale cream flesh; knife marks; rough edges; sizes 1–5 cm; surface moisture.
In-progress cues: Knife in motion; hand stabilizing; other hand guiding; peel scraps on board.
Action by person: Gripping a knife, applying downward pressure, rotating potato between cuts, peeling as needed.
chopping_potato.finished_description:
End state: Small, uniform pieces (roughly 0.8–1.2 cm cubes or evenly sliced strips) with clean, freshly cut surfaces. Skin removed (or skin-on with minimal mottling). Interior pale white/cream; no browning beyond minor oxidation. Dry, with crisp-cut edges; evenly sized, separated, and free of stray peel or large chunks.
After-task activity: The person transfers pieces to a bowl or tray, rinses or pats dry, and proceeds to cooking (sautéing, boiling) or cleans the knife/board.

chopping_jalapeno.progress_description: Start/in-progress states: Whole jalapeño with glossy green skin, stem attached. As chopping begins, it’s halved or cut into irregular chunks; jagged knife marks and uneven edges appear. Seeds and white pith may be exposed or clinging to the knife; surfaces bead with pepper juice. Sizes range from thin slivers to chunky fragments; some pieces are still attached or only partially separated. The handler’s knife is in motion, fingers curled back, other hand stabilizing the pepper on the cutting board; pile on board is uneven, with scattered seeds.
chopping_jalapeno.finished_description: End state: uniform diced jalapeños (roughly 3–5 mm cubes) or thin slices, with seeds and membranes largely removed; skin bright green and glossy, interior pale green; crisp, juicy texture with surface moisture; no stems attached; pieces evenly sized for consistent cooking. The person finished with this task might be sweeping the cut pieces into a bowl or tray, wiping the board or knife, and moving on to the next step (sautéing, adding to salsa, or mixing into a dish).

chopping_zucchini.progress_description: Start state: a whole zucchini with trimmed ends resting on a cutting board; dark-green, striped skin and firm, pale-green flesh. In-progress frames feature partial cuts: round cross-sections (2–6 mm thick), elongated sticks, or irregular chunks; some pieces remain connected to the stem or at the tip. Cut surfaces are fresh, pale, and moist, showing knife ridges. The knife may be mid-stroke or resting; one hand stabilizes the zucchini while the other guides or slices. Pieces may be scattered or piled, with varying thickness and alignment.
chopping_zucchini.finished_description: End state: zucchini is uniformly cut into bite-size pieces, typically 1–2 cm dice or 3–4 mm thick rounds/slivers, depending on technique. The skin remains green with pale green flesh and pale seeds; interior is crisp and moist with minimal browning. Cut surfaces are clean and smooth, free of ragged edges. The pieces are evenly sized, stackable, and ready for cooking or garnish. The person finished may be scooping pieces into a bowl or container, wiping the knife/board, or moving the chopped zucchini to a pan or pot for cooking.

chopping_chili.progress_description: Start state: whole chilies with glossy skin and intact stems; colors green, red, or yellow. In-progress: halves or quarters exposing pale flesh and seeds; jagged, uneven cuts; pieces vary from thin slivers to chunky chunks; moist, shiny surfaces with juice beads; knife marks on the pieces and cutting board; some peppers still joined at stems or by uncut sections; hands and knife show steady chopping motion.
chopping_chili.finished_description: End state: chili is uniformly chopped into small pieces—diced 1–5 mm or a fine mince—depending on technique. Color ranges with variety: red, green, orange, or yellow; flesh crisp, not mushy; surface shows knife texture; seeds may be present if not de-seeded. No large stems; minimal moisture on pieces. The person is likely transferring the chopped chili to a bowl or pan, then wiping the knife and cleaning the cutting area in preparation for cooking.

chopping_egg.progress_description: Start or interim state: A single egg sits on a cutting board, shell intact or cracked. In progress: shell fragments scattered, egg either raw (glossy, translucent whites with liquid yolk near cuts) or boiled (opaque whites, crumbly edges, yellow yolk). Pieces vary in shape: slivers, wedges, and irregular fragments; sizes range from tiny dice to larger chunks. Surfaces may be smooth from clean cuts or jagged from uneven pressure; edges can be curved as the knife rotates. The worker is slicing with a blade, lifting and repositioning pieces, and collecting them into a bowl or pile.
chopping_egg.finished_description: End state: hard-boiled eggs chopped into uniform small pieces, typically 2–5 mm dice or coarse crumbles. White and yolk are visible with yolk flecks; edges clean-cut or slightly jagged; texture crumbly yet cohesive; surface dry to slightly moist, not runny; no shells. They rest in a bowl or plate, evenly distributed, ready for mixing with mayo or other ingredients. The person finished with chopping may be transferring to a mixing bowl, stirring, or adding to a salad or egg salad, then cleaning the knife and board.

chopping_pecan.progress_description: Start frames show whole pecans (in shells or shelled halves) on a cutting surface, with dark brown shells and pale tan interiors. In-progress frames reveal cracked shells and fragmented kernels, with some exposed pale meat; pieces vary from slivers to irregular chunks. Shapes are uneven; some shards, some rounded bits. Colors span shell brown to nut meat tan, with oily or matte surfaces. The person is making mid-stroke chops or taps with a knife or mallet, hands gripping firmly, kernels and shell fragments accumulating on the board.
chopping_pecan.finished_description: End state: chopped pecan meat in a bowl or on a prep surface. Pieces range from coarse fragments to fine crumbs, irregular triangles and shards about 2–6 mm (coarse) or 0.5–1 mm (fine). Color is tan to light brown with darker speckles; surface is dry, matte, and not oily. Consistency is crumbly but discrete, with no large whole halves. The person finished might be scooping into a bowl, sprinkling over batter, or wiping the knife and cleaning the cutting board.

chopping_ginger.progress_description: Start/intermediate states: the rhizome sits with rough tan skin and a pale yellow, fibrous interior exposed where peeled. As chopping begins, the knife nears a curved, knobby surface; surfaces show inconsistent thickness. Shavings range from fine, translucent slivers to irregular chunks; pieces are elongated, wedge-shaped, or cubed, with jagged, moist edges. The cut surface is moist and stringy, with visible fibrous strands and small juicy droplets. Some peel remains attached or curling away; some portions remain whole or partially cut, yielding a mix of thicknesses and irregular shapes.
chopping_ginger.finished_description: End state: peeled ginger has been cut into uniform pieces. For minced ginger: particles about 1–2 mm, irregular yet fine, pale yellow-brown; moist, slightly fibrous; no skin or large chunks. For julienne: slender matchsticks 2–4 mm wide, translucent edges. In either case, a loose pile or spread on the board or into a bowl. The worker might be scraping the blade, gathering the ginger into a bowl, wiping the board, or prepping to add it to a pan.

chopping_coriander.progress_description: During chopping, coriander exists in transition: a pile with mixed intact sprigs, torn leaf sections, and various-sized cut pieces. Stems show partial trimming; thicker stems may still be connected to leaf clusters. Leaves range from bright to darker greens; surfaces glisten with a bit of water. Shapes are irregular—coarse ribbons, small fragments, and jagged edges. A knife may be mid-stroke, twisting and pressing on the board; fingers guide the cut, while the other hand gathers and slides pieces into a gathering heap, occasionally sweeping scraps aside.
chopping_coriander.finished_description: End state: cilantro leaves and tender stems uniformly minced into small, irregularly shaped pieces about 2–4 mm across; color bright to mid-green with no large intact leaves or thick stems. The texture is finely chopped, slightly fluffy, damp from rinsing, and evenly distributed; no visible clumps of moisture. Pieces lie on cutting board or in a small pile, sometimes collected in a bowl or on a spoon. The person is typically transferring the chopped cilantro to a pan, bowl, or recipe, wiping the board, and cleaning the knife.

chopping_basil.progress_description: In early stages: a small bundle of fresh basil leaves with bright green color, intact stems, and a clean cutting board. In-progress states show a mix of whole leaves and torn fragments, varying in size from large leaf shards to thin ribbons, some leaves with blade marks, edges uneven. The texture is glossy and slightly damp; stems may be partially exposed. The practitioner is holding the knife with a guiding hand, pressing leaves against the board, gathering clumps, and making short slicing or tearing motions, often rotating the stack as the motion continues.
chopping_basil.finished_description: End state: basil leaves are uniformly chopped into small pieces (roughly 1–3 mm dice) or thin chiffonade ribbons; no large stems or wilted parts; color bright green with a glossy surface from essential oils; texture soft, springy, and moist but not mushy; pieces cling together slightly and have a fresh aroma. The work surface shows even distribution of fragments. The person might be sprinkling chopped basil over pasta, sauce, or soups, folding it into a pesto base, or garnishing a finished dish, having completed the chopping task.

chopping_avocado.progress_description:
Whole avocado on a board; oblong shape, dark green mottled skin, stem cap present; firm to touch.
Halved lengthwise; pit visible in one half; pale green flesh near edge; skin still attached around the edge.
Skin partially peeled from one half; exposed flesh bright green, glossy, with slight moisture.
Flesh scored with shallow parallel or cross lines; blade tip rests in fruit; stabilized by the opposite hand.
Fruit rotated and blade follows the cut lines; seams visible but still joined.
chopping_avocado.finished_description: End state: avocado flesh detached from skin and pit, cut into uniform pieces—diced cubes about 0.5–1 cm or thin slices—depending on technique. Color: bright green to yellow-green, with a creamy, buttery texture; surfaces may show slight browning on exposure. The board, knife, and hands should be free of flesh fragments; juice squeezed to prevent browning. The pieces are gathered in a bowl or on a plate for serving, or folded into a salad. The person may be cleaning the knife, wiping the board, or transferring pieces to a container.

chopping_broccoli.progress_description: Start: whole broccoli crown with tight green florets and pale stalk. In progress: florets partially detached, stems cut into shorter chunks; pieces vary from large florets to smaller fragments. Colors: dark-green florets, lighter-green stalks, pale interior where cut. Textures range from crisp, moist exterior to fibrous cut surfaces. Knife marks visible; moisture on board. The worker holds the knife and rotates the crown, slicing through stems, trimming leaves, and rearranging pieces as they are cut.
chopping_broccoli.finished_description: End state: broccoli prepped with florets separated and cut into uniform bite-size pieces (about 1–1.5 cm), stems trimmed and peeled, cut into small coins or sticks. Color is bright to mid-green; exposed cuts are pale green; edges clean and dry with no brown spots or yellowing. Pieces are evenly sized for uniform cooking; texture is crisp-tender, not mushy. The worker finished might be spreading pieces on a sheet for roasting, transferring to a bowl for steaming/blanching, or washing hands and readying cookware.

chopping_scallion.progress_description: Starting state: whole scallion with white bulb, green stalks, roots trimmed. In progress: knife mid-slice with a partially divided stalk; some pieces are white-rounded cross-sections and green-tipped shreds; irregular thickness, some long strips, some coins, with varying textures from crisp edges to slightly damp interiors. Pieces scattered on board; moisture beads on the surface; hands guiding the knife, pushing chopped portions aside, scooping with the other hand or spatula. The pile contains mixed partials, some intact segments still connected to the base.
chopping_scallion.finished_description: End state: scallions finely chopped into uniform small pieces about 2–5 mm, mixing white bulbs with green stalks. Color ranges from white to pale green with darker green tips; shape is small irregular chunks (or short cylinders) with a crisp, moist texture and no long strands or uncut pieces. The person finished with this task is likely transferring the chopped scallions to a bowl or pan, or sprinkling them over a dish for garnish or quick sauté, prepping for cooking.

chopping_lettuce.progress_description: Start: a whole head or loose leaves on a cutting board; leaves are bright green with pale cores, outer leaves darker and crisp; stems visible and moisture on the surface. In progress: knife mid-stroke, partial cuts producing ribbons and irregular chunks; some leaves still attached to the core; pieces vary in size from fine slivers to larger shards; edges torn or jagged; one hand stabilizes, fingers curled back, the other guides the blade.
chopping_lettuce.finished_description: End state: uniformly chopped lettuce pieces, about 0.5–2 cm, in irregular ribbons or cubes, bright green with pale cores, crisp and relatively dry, with no large stems or brown edges. Pieces are evenly sized, free of soggy clumps. The person might be transferring the lettuce to a salad bowl or storage container, patting it dry if needed, and clearing the cutting board or putting away the knife.

chopping_cauliflower.progress_description: Starting state: a whole cauliflower head on a cutting board, leaves trimmed around the crown. The surface is matte ivory with a pale green core exposed where the stem is cut. In-progress states show florets beginning to loosen from the crown; some large segments remain attached, others are partially separated. The knife is held at an angle with a rocking, pruning motion, hands stabilizing the head and guiding splits. Wetness from washing may bead on the pale surface; edges show rough, uneven cuts and jagged interfaces where the florets are being pried apart.
chopping_cauliflower.finished_description: End state: cauliflower chopped into uniform bite-sized pieces (roughly 1–2 cm florets) with stems trimmed away; color pale white to ivory; surface dry and matte with no brown spots; moisture minimal; pieces may be distinct florets or a rice-like granule if pulsed. Typically gathered on a cutting board or in a bowl, ready for roasting, steaming, sautéing, or storage. The worker is likely transferring pieces to a pan or steamer, or packing them into a container, while wiping the knife and board.

chopping_almond.progress_description: At the start or in intermediate states, almonds show a range of forms on a cutting board. Whole almonds with brown skins remain; some halves and slivers sit alongside irregular chunks. Sizes span from fine crumbs to about a centimeter across. Surfaces reveal knife facets and occasional broken edges; colors mix pale interior with tan skin. Some dust or meal may coat the board. The person is likely slicing with a chef’s knife, applying downward or rocking motions, gathering or brushing pieces as they work.
chopping_almond.finished_description:
- End state of chopping almond: Small, irregular pieces about 2–5 mm across with jagged knife-cut edges. Color beige to light brown; matte, dry surface. Texture is crumbly but discrete; no whole almonds remain, though a light dusting of almond meal may be on the cutting board.
 - What the person finished might be doing: Transferring the chopped almonds to a bowl or pan, sprinkling them into a dish, or prepping them for packaging.

chopping_sausage.progress_description: At the start or mid-process, the sausage shows mixed geometry: intact links, and partially cut segments. Slices range from translucent rounds to crescent halves and uneven chunks. Edges are rough or jagged; cross-sections reveal granular pink meat with a glossy casing. Surfaces may bead moisture or light juice. On the cutting board, the person holds or guides a knife, applying pressure, rotating the sausage, and pausing between cuts as they progress, with pieces being separated or restacked.
chopping_sausage.finished_description: End state: Uniformly diced sausage into small cubes about 6–8 mm per side, evenly sized with square-ish edges and a smooth, slightly glossy surface. Pink-red interior with white fat flecks; casing removed; texture firm yet yielding. Moisture not pooling. Pieces may be loosely spread or neatly arranged in a tray, ready for cooking or packaging. The person finishing the task is likely sweeping the board, collecting the dice into a container, or moving them to storage and labeling for the next step.

chopping_pineapple.progress_description: Starting state: a whole pineapple with crown attached; brown-green mottled rind, rough texture, visible eyes; surface slick with juice. In progress: rind partially removed, pale yellow to golden flesh exposed; some brown core visible. Knife marks: vertical and horizontal cuts, scoring ridges. Shapes seen: long wedges, irregular chunks, strips; sizes range from large to small as chopping continues. Color and texture: flesh becomes more uniform yellow; rind edges peeled, some fibrous strands. Work actions: stabilizing fruit, trimming eyes, guiding knife, rotating fruit to continue cutting.
chopping_pineapple.finished_description: End state: peeled and cored pineapple flesh cut into uniform bite-sized pieces (about 1–2 cm cubes or evenly sized chunks). No rind, no eyes; trimmed cores not visible. Color is bright yellow, flesh glossy and juicy with fine fibers. Pieces are consistent in size for even cooking or mixing, with little browning. The worker is likely transferring the pieces to a storage container or bowl and tidying the cutting area for cleanup or next steps.

chopping_date.progress_description: Start or intermediate chopping states: whole dates with pits intact; dates halved or minced; mix of intact, sliced, and chunked pieces. Shapes: irregular rectangles, wedges, or sticks; uneven sizes and cut surfaces. Color: dark brown skin; cut surfaces light tan to caramel; some pieces glossy and sticky with date syrup. Consistency: soft, chewy, or slightly fibrous with exposed moist interior. On the board: juice or syrup pooling; bits of flesh clinging to knife. The person may be slicing, twisting, and guiding the blade, occasionally resetting grip.
chopping_date.finished_description: End state: chopped dates appear as uniform bite-size pieces (roughly 5–8 mm cubes or 5–10 mm ribbons), evenly cut and separated. Color tan to deep amber-brown; surfaces moist, slightly glossy, with a sticky sheen. Texture soft and chewy; pits removed; no whole fruits or large chunks remain. In the shot, the worker is scooping pieces into a bowl, wiping the knife, or preparing to mix them into a dish.

chopping_leek.progress_description: A leek starts as a long, cylindrical stalk: white base widening to pale green, with darker green tops and dirt-filled crevices between leaves; the flesh is firm and slightly waxy. In progress you may see the root end trimmed and the stalk laid on a cutting board; the knife is mid-stroke or poised. Leek may be cut lengthwise into halves or into crosswise rings; some sections stay connected, others are already separated into long strips or irregular chunks. Colors range white to pale to bright green; surfaces glisten with moisture as processing continues.
chopping_leek.finished_description: End state: chopped leek appears as uniform pieces, typically small dice about 2–4 mm or fine slices. Colors: white to pale green; edges slightly translucent. Texture: crisp-tender with a moist surface; root end trimmed, dirt removed, no dark green tops, no long fibers. Pieces evenly distributed, ready for cooking or seasoning. The person finished might be transferring the chopped leek to a bowl or pan, wiping the board, or sweeping up and moving toward sautéing.

chopping_butter.progress_description:
Start: Solid butter block on a cutting board; pale yellow; smooth, firm surface; intact edges.
Early cuts: Blade makes shallow incisions; interior appears lighter and slightly softer; small slivers begin.
Mid-cut: Irregular chunks and shavings; surface ridges; mixed piece sizes; oil sheen on the board from exposed fat.
Person’s actions: Grips the knife with one hand, steadies the block with the other, guides the blade through, rotating the block as needed.
chopping_butter.finished_description:
End state: Butter is diced into uniform, cold cubes (about 1 cm or 1/2 inch per side) or thin coins, with clean knife edges. Color pale yellow; texture solid and firm, not melted; surface slightly glossy and dry to the touch. Pieces are neatly arranged on the cutting surface or gathered in a bowl/parchment tray; no large chunks remain.
 

 Post-task actions: the knife is wiped or cleaned, the cubes are stacked or collected, and the butter is returned to the fridge or transferred to a pan or mixing bowl for the recipe.

chopping_chilies.progress_description: At the start or mid-process, whole chilies or large segments sit on the board. Some peppers remain intact; others are halved, or thinly sliced, exposing pale flesh and white seeds. Knife marks show rough, jagged or clean cuts with uneven edges. Chopped pieces appear as irregular shapes—wedges, ribbons, and chunky fragments—varying in size from centimeters to tiny shards. Colors reflect ripeness: green, red, orange, or yellow, with glossy skins and matte interiors. Surfaces may be slick or moist, seeds clustered or scattered. The task is ongoing, with pieces at mixed states of cut.
chopping_chilies.finished_description: End state: chilies chopped into uniform small pieces (diced/minced) about 2–5 mm; shape irregular but size-consistent. Color matches the variety (green, red, orange, yellow); surface glossy with a bit of oil; seeds mostly removed or dispersed. Moisture present but not soggy. The cut pile sits in a prep bowl or on a board. The person then transfers to a pan or mixing bowl, or cleans the knife/board after packing away.

chopping_capsicum.progress_description:
Start state: whole capsicum on a board, glossy skin, stem attached, color varies (green/red/yellow/orange), about 3–4 inches across.
In-progress states: cut into halves or large wedges, interior ribs and pale membranes exposed, seeds partly attached or loosened; surfaces moist.
Intermediate shapes: long strips, broad ribbons, or irregular chunks; edges may be straight or jagged; sizes range from finger-width to palm-sized.
Action: the person uses a sharp knife, guiding with fingers, rotates the pepper to expose new sides, and moves fragments toward a cutting area.
chopping_capsicum.finished_description: End state: chopped capsicum pieces uniform in size and shape per cut style. Common forms: dice (~8–12 mm cubes) or julienne strips (~2–3 mm by 1–2 cm). Color varies by variety (green, red, yellow, orange); surfaces crisp and moist; seeds and core largely removed; no large wedges. Pieces loosely scattered on a cutting board or in a bowl. The person may be transferring chopped peppers to a container or pan, or tidying the board, knife set aside, ready for cooking.

chopping_olive.progress_description: Start state: a pile of whole olives—green, black, brown—glossy skins, oval to spherical shapes, sizes from marble to olive, some with pits visible or intact, firm to the touch. In-progress states show partial cuts: halves or quarters, irregular wedges, or thin slices; exposed pale-green to brown flesh, occasionally pitted remnants; moisture and olive juice bead on the cutting surface; skins may be wrinkled from pressure. The knife hand is steady, chiseling or slicing through with a rocking or straight-down motion; the board shows a mix of whole and cut pieces, partial pieces, and scattered fragments.
chopping_olive.finished_description:
End state: chopped olives appear as uniform pieces about 2–5 mm, in cubes or irregular chunks. Color ranges from bright green to olive-brown or deep purple-black, with a glossy, slightly oily surface. Skin may be intact; pits removed. Texture is firm yet crumbly, with some paste-like portions from flesh. No whole olives remain.
 
What the person might be doing next: transferring to a bowl or pan, scraping the cutting board and knife, or starting to sauté or mix olives into a dish.

chopping_thyme.progress_description: Start and in-progress states show whole thyme sprigs with woody stems or loose bundles. Leaves are bright to olive green with a waxy sheen; stems are brown and fibrous. Incomplete cuts show mixed sizes: intact leaves, partially stripped sprigs, and irregular chunks or tiny fragments. Knife in motion or resting near the cutting board; hands grip the stem or knife with a chopping or rocking action. Some moisture and herb oils tint the board; cut ends are jagged, and air carries a fresh thyme aroma.
chopping_thyme.finished_description: End state: thyme minced into very small, uniform green specks (roughly 1–2 mm) with woody stems removed. Leaves are evenly chopped, showing a light sheen from essential oils and no visible stems. Texture is granular, not fluffy. The cook is likely finishing by transferring to a pan or mixing into a sauce or marinade, or wiping the knife and gathering the chopped thyme for garnish or incorporation.

grilling_chicken.progress_description: Start/intermediate states: raw chicken pieces on the grill appear pale pink with translucent edges and a glossy, moist surface; shapes irregular but intact; size largely unchanged except for moisture loss. As grilling proceeds: exterior browns slightly and shows light sear lines; edges set while centers stay somewhat translucent; juices bead and steam; fat renders and pieces may curl. The cook is placing pieces, flipping with tongs, rotating for even contact, and adjusting heat or basting as needed.
grilling_chicken.finished_description: End state: chicken pieces are fully cooked, shape largely intact though slightly shrunken; exterior golden-brown with visible Maillard crust and grill marks; surface shows some crispness; interior is opaque white with a safe temperature of at least 165°F (74°C) near the thickest part; juices run clear rather than pink; texture firm yet moist, not rubbery; skin-on pieces are crisp. The dish is plated or arranged on a tray. The worker is likely resting the meat, slicing or portioning, checking temp, labeling/plating, and cleaning tools.

grilling_steak.progress_description: Start state: raw steak on grill, shape approximately rectangular with uniform thickness; surface is moist, red-pink center visible in cross-section; marbling white; edges with some fat. In progress: steak makes contact with hot grates; parallel sear lines appear; surface browning starts near contact, pale to tan; fat begins to render; juices bead and hiss as steam rises; overall color shifts from bright pink toward deeper brown on the exterior; slight warping or curling may occur.
grilling_steak.finished_description: End state: a steak, 1 to 1.5 inches thick, contracted slightly in size, with a crusty, even sear and distinct grill marks. Exterior is golden to dark brown; surface may show a light gloss from retained juices. The interior shows a doneness-dependent color: rare (warm red center) to well-done (brown/gray center); most common is pink-to-rosy in the middle, with a juicy, slightly firm texture. The steak rests to redistribute juices. The final action is resting, slicing, and plating, often tented with foil or being portioned on a board.

grilling_corn.progress_description: Start/intermediate states of grilling corn: cobs placed on a hot grill, either fully husked or partially peeled so kernels are visible. Shape: uniform cylindrical with rounded ends; length about workable size. Color/texture: bright yellow kernels, some translucence, lightly glistening with oil; husks green and taut or peeling away; silk strands present. Early heat causes faint browning specks and subtle grill marks, not full char. Edges of husk may curl; kernels remain firm, with moisture visible on surface. The person is turning, repositioning, or brushing oil/seasoning, avoiding full cooking yet.
grilling_corn.finished_description: End state: grilled corn on the cob with husks removed, kernels plump and evenly aligned, ranging from golden-yellow to amber with light char and blistering from direct heat. The kernels are tender with a slight snap, surfaced in a buttery, glossy sheen with caramelized edges. Cob may show grill marks but remains intact. If shaved, kernels come off cleanly. The cook is likely resting or plating, brushing with melted butter or oil, and sprinkling salt or herbs before presenting the corn on a platter or skewers.

grilling_fish.progress_description: Start/intermediate grilling state: raw fillet or portion placed skin side down on a hot grill; skin is shiny, scales intact, surface moist. Outer edges begin firming and curling; the flesh near the surface is translucent pinkish-gray while the center remains soft and cooler. Light grill marks appear; juices bead and steam rises from where heat penetrates. The cook uses tongs to reposition, rotate 90–180 degrees, brush oil, and adjust fire while testing translucence and firmness.
grilling_fish.finished_description: End state: a grilled fish piece (fillet or whole) with a crisp, golden-brown exterior and clear grill marks; skin crispy if left on. The interior flesh is opaque white, firm yet moist, and flakes easily under gentle pressure; minimal raw-looking areas. The piece may have contracted slightly and curled at the edges, and its size is modestly reduced from raw due to moisture loss. Post-cook actions: the cook rests briefly, then plates and garnishes, possibly slices, and serves with lemon or sauce.

grilling_pineapple.progress_description: Start/intermediate states: Pineapple pieces (rings or wedges) trimmed to uniform thickness (0.8–1.3 cm), skin removed, bright yellow and moist. On a hot grill, edges may curl slightly; surfaces look translucent as juices begin to release. Tiny beads of sugary moisture form and faint grill lines appear. The cook uses tongs or skewers, rotates pieces, and may brush with oil or glaze. Steam rises, aromas intensify, and the piece remains visibly intact under ongoing heat.
grilling_pineapple.finished_description: End state: grilled pineapple slices or rings retain shape but show slight shrinkage. Color ranges from golden-yellow to amber with distinct dark grill marks and caramelized edges. Surface is glossy from released juices; exterior is lightly crisp while interior remains juicy and tender. Core is still firm, not mushy. Size reduction is modest due to dehydration. Presentation is plated or skewered with visible glaze. The task’s finished state implies the person is plating/serving, possibly tasting or documenting the result.

grilling_salmon.progress_description: Start or in-progress states: A salmon fillet (skin-on) lies on a preheated grill, rectangular and centered; thickness uniform, edges flush to grates. The flesh is a translucent pink with a glossy oil sheen; surface still soft and pliable. Some moisture beads appear, and the sides may begin to curl slightly. Sizzle is audible; initial, faint grill marks may be forming. The cook uses tongs or spatula to adjust contact, possibly repositioning, lightly pressing to minimize curling, or applying marinade/baste while heat penetrates.
grilling_salmon.finished_description:
End state: salmon fillets uniform in shape (oval with tapered ends), about 4–6 oz each and ~1 inch thick. Exterior golden-brown crust; skin crisp if present. Flesh opaque pink-orange, center non-translucent; firm yet moist and flaky, with lightly shimmering juices. Rest briefly off heat before plating.
 
The person finished might be plating and garnishing, or tidying the grill and turning off the heat.

grilling_onion.progress_description: Onion slices, rings, or wedges rest on a hot grill. They are pale-white to translucent, still firm with gentle give. Surfaces show light sear lines; moisture beads on cut faces. Edges begin to soften and curl as heat penetrates; centers stay opaque. Sizzling steam hints at moisture loss. The cook uses tongs to turn pieces, possibly brushes with oil or seasonings, and monitors heat to maintain even translucence and prevent uneven cooking or burning.
grilling_onion.finished_description: End state: onions grilled to tender, jammy texture with caramelized surfaces. Sliced rings are translucent, reduced in size, with golden-brown centers and dark grill-marked edges; color ranges from pale yellow to deep amber. Whole onions collapse slightly but stay cohesive, yielding soft, pliable segments. Aroma is sweet and smoky. If finished, the cook is removing them from the grate with tongs, transferring to a plate or skillet, and may glaze, salt, or oil-toss them, then serve as burger toppings, fajita filling, or in salads.

grilling_bread.progress_description: In start or mid-steps, bread sits on a hot grill. Shape remains flat and intact; edges may curl or retreat slightly; surface may puff tiny amounts. Size largely unchanged, with possible slight expansion from steam. Color stays pale cream to light tan; surface is moist, sometimes glossy, with small bubbles as moisture escapes. Grill marks begin to form as lines or speckled browning, and spots blister. Texture shifts from soft doughy to tacky around the surface; aroma rises as sizzle continues. The person might be flipping, pressing, or brushing with oil/butter, adjusting position.
grilling_bread.finished_description: End state: bread items evenly toasted, uniform slices or pieces, golden-brown with defined grill marks. Crust crisp, surface dry, interior warm and soft with slight tenderness. Color ranges from light amber to dark bronze; edges may be lightly charred. Exterior crackling when bitten; aroma of toasted butter. They may have been buttered or seasoned. The person finished may be removing from grill, resting briefly, then buttering/serving, stacking on a plate or placing on a board for service.

grilling_tomato.progress_description: Start or in-progress states: Tomatoes are on the grill in whole or cut form; skins are smooth and taut when fresh, varying in size from cherry to Roma. Early heat yields glistening moisture and faint blisters; cut sides steam, colors intensify from bright red to deeper pink/orange; the flesh remains firm. As grilling continues, grill marks appear, skins blister or lift, and edges soften while moisture beads and pools on the surface. The cook flips and rotates with tongs, presses lightly with a spatula, and oils or seasons to support even sear.
grilling_tomato.finished_description: End state: grilled tomato(s) are softened and slightly shriveled, with blistered, charred skin and visible grill marks. Color deepens from bright red to red-brown near the edges; flesh becomes tender, juicy, and somewhat pulpy near the core. Size/shape: whole tomatoes may shrink slightly but stay round; sliced halves/wedges flatten with a curved profile. Surface may be wrinkled with blistering. After cooking, the chef typically removes them with tongs, rests briefly, and proceeds to slice, chop, or toss into a dish.

grilling_zucchini.progress_description: Fresh zucchini are firm, elongated cylinders (6–8 inches long, 1–2 inches diameter), with glossy dark green skin and pale green-white flesh; ends trimmed; either whole or cut into rounds, half-moons, or spears. Surface may be dry or have droplets; seeds visible. In progress, on a preheated grill or pan; oil brushed on; pieces sizzling; light browning at edges; subtle grill lines; some curling; spaced to heat evenly. The person is slicing, trimming, oiling, placing on grill, flipping, adjusting spacing, and seasoning.
grilling_zucchini.finished_description: End state: zucchini slices or spears are tender-crisp with charred grill marks. Exterior dark-green, possibly blistered; interior pale-green and juicy. Typical thickness: 1/4–1/2 inch; shape: rounds or lengthwise planks. Surface glistens with oil; color shows golden-brown edges and some caramelization; no mushiness. They retain shape, slight snap when bitten. In final frame, the cook has moved them to a plate or tray, possibly resting, lightly seasoned, and may be tossing with olive oil, lemon, herbs, or transitioning to serving.

grilling_asparagus.progress_description: Start or intermediate States of grilling asparagus: Raw spears are straight, slender (15–25 cm long, 0.4–1 cm dia), smooth, firm, with bright green color and closed, tightly packed tips. On the grill, spears bend slightly as heat softens; surface shows a glossy oil sheen and occasional blistering. Grill marks appear as dark lines; spears tilt or rest across bars, turned with tongs. The cook brushes with oil, adjusts distance from heat, and monitors for even exposure and pace of charring without implying the final state.
grilling_asparagus.finished_description: End state: uniformly sized spears, 6–8 inches long, bright green with golden-brown caramelization and distinct grill marks; tips tender-crisp, stalks blistered and lightly shriveled at the surface; outer skin lightly charred, moisture glistening; texture tender with a gentle bite and no raw centers. The plate shows an oil sheen and light seasoning. The cook may be resting, tossing in a final drizzle of olive oil and lemon, or plating for service.

grilling_bacon.progress_description: Start: raw bacon slices lie flat, pink flesh with opaque white fat; edges aligned, slight moisture. Early cook: fat begins to render; surface glistens with oil; pink-to-translucent color appears; edges shrink and curl; strips may shorten as fat renders; bubbles form along fat; steam audible; slices may overlap. Midway: more curling and puffing, uneven thickness shows; some parts lift from pan, others stay down; fat pooling in pan; spatters heard; cook flips with tongs, rotates pieces to expose uncooked side; heat adjusted as needed.
grilling_bacon.finished_description: End state: bacon pieces are uniformly browned and crisp, with rendered fat absorbed or drained, edges curled slightly, pieces flat or lightly arched. Color ranges from pale golden-brown to deep amber, with some darker tips. Surface dry to the touch, visible crisp texture, and a light grease sheen on the plate. Some variation in thickness is normal. When done, the cook removes the pan from heat or transfers bacon to a plate lined with paper towels to drain, then serves or holds briefly while finishing cleanup.

grilling_eggplant.progress_description: Start/in progress: Eggplant pieces (1–2 cm thick slices or halves) sit on a hot grill, skin intact or scored, deep purple exterior with pale, moist flesh. As grilling proceeds, surfaces blister and brown in patches; skin may curl or pucker; crosshatch marks or straight grill lines appear; moisture beads on the surface and steam rises from the cut areas. The flesh near exposed surfaces becomes softer and more translucent, while the fruit shrinks slightly. The cook flips, rotates, and presses with tongs, brushing oil and adjusting heat, all while heat penetrates the interior.
grilling_eggplant.finished_description: End state: grilled eggplant with blistered, charred skin and a soft, creamy interior. The shape remains intact if whole or halved; the flesh may sag slightly. Size is similar to the starting piece, often a bit smaller from shrinking. Exterior skin ranges from purple to brown with clear grill marks. Flesh is pale cream, silky and spreadable when mashed; texture can be tender with a slight bite. Aroma is smoky with olive oil sheen. The cook may be plating, peeling charred skin, slicing into rounds, or mashing/assembling for dip or a dish.

grilling_shrimp.progress_description: Start: raw shrimp are gray, translucent, and flexible, often shell-on with tails attached; they may be marinated or salted. In progress: shrimp curl more tightly as heat penetrates; surface shows a wet, glistening sheen; edges turn from translucent gray to pale pink, while the center remains partly translucent; grill marks appear on the exterior; moisture beads on the surface; shrinkage is mild. The cook uses tongs to flip the shrimp, rotating for even heat, brushing oil or marinade, and adjusting flame to maintain steady sizzle.
grilling_shrimp.finished_description: End state of grilled shrimp: Shrimp are fully opaque with a pink-to-orange hue; the center is white and non-translucent. They have firm, springy texture and curl into a loose “C” or “S” shape. Exterior shows light caramelization and grill marks; surface may be glossy from moisture or butter. Size remains largely the same with slight shrinkage. If shells were on, shells are pink/red; peeled meat is pink-white. The cook has likely removed them from the grill, rested briefly, and is plating or skewering for serving, perhaps with lemon or butter.

grilling_sausage.progress_description: Start/intermediate states: Raw sausage links lie on the grill, casing pale and translucent, moisture glistening. As heat builds, fat begins to render, surface takes on a light gloss, edges may curl and small cracks appear in the seam. Faint grill marks form and sizzle persists; the interior stays pinkish/soft while heat penetrates. Juices bead and steam escapes; no final color yet. The cook flips with tongs, repositions across heat zones, and tests firmness to gauge progress.
grilling_sausage.finished_description: End state: sausages are evenly browned with slight curling and crisp casing. They appear plump and uniform in length, slightly expanded from cooking. Exterior shows dark grill marks and caramelization; the surface is crisp, not burnt. Inside is opaque and firm, with juices visible at the cut ends; no raw pink center. Size is similar to pre-cook but a bit larger from expansion, with some moisture loss. The cook is likely resting, slicing, or plating for serving.

grilling_cheese.progress_description: Start/intermediate state: Cheese on a hot grill or pan as slices or blocks begin to soften. Shapes remain rectangular/square or slightly irregular, about 2–4 inches across, 0.2–0.5 inch thick. Color shifts from opaque pale to translucent edges; surface gleams with moisture as the interior softens. Edges may curl or sag slightly; tiny bubbles or oil beads form on the surface; grill marks begin to appear as the cheese adheres to heat. The cook may brush with fat, reposition slices, and press or flip gently to monitor progress.
grilling_cheese.finished_description: End state: a grilled cheese piece with a crisp, browned crust and a molten, stretchy interior. Form is rectangular or sandwich-like; thickness about 2–3 cm; length ~8–12 cm. Surface shows even golden-brown color with diagonal grill marks; outer crust firm, center melted and gooey; edges slightly charred; moisture may ooze from seams. The cook is likely removing it from the pan, resting briefly, then slicing or plating, and/or cleaning up the area and tagging the shot for the dataset.

grilling_potato.progress_description: Start/intermediate states show potatoes cut into wedges, rounds, cubes, or small whole tubers, varied in size from bite-sized to thick chunks. Raw flesh appears pale ivory; surfaces may be glossy from oil. During progress, the exterior begins to brown faintly, with light grill marks and uneven color; the interior remains firm and pale, sometimes becoming slightly translucent at cut faces. Sizzling and steam rise from the hot grate; some pieces are being turned or moved with tongs, oil or seasonings brushed on, and pieces are grouped on the grate but not yet tender throughout.
grilling_potato.finished_description: End state: bite-sized or whole potato pieces with even browning; exterior crisp and slightly charred with parallel grill marks; interior fully cooked to a tender, fluffy center. Color ranges from golden yellow to deep amber/brown; surface may glisten with oil. Size/shape reflect cut: wedges, rounds, or cubes with crisp edges. The finished task typically shows potatoes resting on a plate or tray, ready for plating; the cook may season with salt, pepper, herbs, or butter, then present for serving.

grilling_pepper.progress_description: Start: whole bell pepper with glossy, intact skin (green, red, or yellow), firm texture; or large, cleanly cut halves/strips with exposed pale flesh and seeds. In progress: on the hot grill, the skin shows blisters and begins to lift; distinct grill marks appear; edges curl and shrink as moisture evaporates; surface becomes glossy from juices; pepper softens but remains weighted by its core; droplets bead on the surface; the cook rotates with tongs, repositions for even heat, and moves pieces as they blister and sweat.
grilling_pepper.finished_description: End state: Grilled bell peppers show blistered, charred skin that peels away easily; the exterior is blackened in spots but the flesh underneath is soft and juicy. Colors range from roasted red/orange/yellow to darkened hues; the peppers have collapsed slightly, become wrinkled, and reduced in volume. Flesh is tender, slightly smoky, with visible juices; seeds and core largely removed or ready to remove. The chef or cook is likely peeling the skins, removing seeds, and slicing or chopping into strips (for salads, toppings, or sauces).

blending_banana.progress_description: Start/intermediate states: Banana peeled; whole fruit or large pieces (about 1–2 cm) visible; skin removed, fruit bright yellow with brown speckles; surface moist and slightly glossy. Mid-way, pieces become irregular chunks; some slices expose pale flesh; browning may start at exposed surfaces. In-progress visuals: in a blender or bowl, pieces move together; uneven texture with visible lumps and some liquid pooling around; sticky residue on sides. Actions by the person: peeling, slicing into chunks, transferring pieces into the blender or bowl, turning on the appliance, keeping pieces moving or scraping the sides during blending.
blending_banana.finished_description: End state: a homogeneous banana puree (or smoothie) with no visible chunks. Color: uniform pale yellow to light tan. Texture: smooth, creamy, thick but scoopable; glossy surface with occasional tiny air bubbles. Shape/size: a single continuous mass in the jar, no discrete pieces; volume matches the input amount. If liquids were added, it’s pourable and thinner. The person finished might be scraping the blender/jar with a spatula, transferring to a container, and cleaning the equipment.

blending_egg.progress_description: Start: eggs cracked into a bowl; yolks intact as glossy discs, whites clear and separate. In progress: yolks begin to break and disperse; whites and yolk form streaks and a pale yellow-white pool. Bubbles appear as mixing starts; surface shimmers with trapped air. The whisk or fork is in motion—circling, whisking, folding—lifting liquid and breaking membranes. Texture remains thin to somewhat viscous; color is uneven, with glossy patches of yolk and translucent whites. Visible seams or strands indicate partial emulsification, not yet uniform.
blending_egg.finished_description: End state: a homogeneous, pale yellow to light beige liquid with no shell fragments or visible chunks. Texture is smooth and pourable to slightly viscous, often with a fine foamy surface from whisking or blending. Color is uniform throughout; no separation into yolk and white. The mixture conforms to the container’s shape, forming a level surface in the bowl or blender. If whipped, tiny air bubbles give a light sheen. The person finished with this task is likely pouring it into a pan to cook scrambled eggs/omelet, or moving to the next step.

blending_tomato.progress_description: Start state: whole or quartered tomatoes with skins, seeds, and varying sizes. As blending begins, you see coarse chunks, wetness on the blade, and streaks of juice on the sides. In progress, pieces break into irregular shapes; the color remains bright red with lighter pulp showing through; some seeds and fibrous strands persist, producing a chunky texture.
