Viscosity is uneven; there may be visible air bubbles and splatter at the lid. The operator pulses, occasionally pauses to scrape the sides with a spatula or uses a tamper while watching the mix. They are actively processing, adjusting and monitoring.
blending_tomato.finished_description:
End state: a smooth, homogeneous tomato puree with uniform red-to-orange-red color, glossy surface, and a pourable-to-spoonable viscosity. No skins, seeds, or visible chunks; no fibrous strands. Particles, if any, are imperceptible (typically <1 mm). The mass forms an amorphous blob in the container, with tiny air bubbles. 

What they might be doing: QA-ing the blend, labeling/annotating frames, exporting metadata for the dataset, and cleaning the equipment before the next shot.

blending_strawberry.progress_description: In early to mid-blend frames, the fruit is only partly processed. Whole berries with stems may be present, alongside halves or quarters, and chunks range roughly 0.5–2 cm. The exterior is glossy red; some flesh is exposed pale pink or white. Juices bead and pool around pieces, and seeds show through; texture varies from intact to chunky, with irregular surfaces. You may see blades in motion, producing partial fragmentation, streaks of puree, and small bubbles. The person is loading strawberries, trimming tops, slicing as needed, and pulsing or scraping the sides with a spatula, pausing between actions.
blending_strawberry.finished_description: End state: a uniform strawberry puree—no large chunks, only tiny seed specks. Color is bright red, evenly distributed, with a glossy, semi-thick liquid texture. Consistency ranges from thick nectar to pourable smoothie, depending on blend time; surface shows small bubbles. The final product is poured into a container or bottle, ready for use. The person finished with the task may be pouring, tasting, or transferring, then cleaning the blender and workspace.

blending_garlic.progress_description:
In start/intermediate blending, you’ll see:
Whole cloves with skins still on or barely peeled; uncut or lightly separated.
Halved or crushed chunks with jagged edges; visible fibers and a damp surface.
Coarse mince: irregular granules of varying size, some damp or oiled sheen.
Early emulsion: small lumps merging into a glossy, sticky mass while larger bits remain recognizable.
You might see garlic juice pooling around pieces. The person is chopping with a knife, crushing in a mortar and pestle, or pulsing a blender with pauses to scrape the bowl.
blending_garlic.finished_description: End state: garlic paste—uniform, cohesive mass with no large chunks. Color ranges ivory to pale yellow; texture smooth to slightly granular, with very small particle size and a glossy or matte surface depending on moisture and any oil added. There may be tiny oil droplets if blended with oil. The person finished might be transferring the paste from the blender to a bowl, scraping the blades, wiping the work area, and preparing to cook, season, or refrigerate the paste.

blending_butter.progress_description: Start: a solid butter block, cold, cut into chunks in a bowl. In progress: the edges soften and smear as a whisk or spatula works through them; chunks yield to ribbons of fat, with some glossy specks still intact. The surface is patchy, pale yellow and white, and small air pockets begin to form. The person pulses or folds, occasionally scraping the bowl to bring unmixed portions toward the center, reworking with each pass.
blending_butter.finished_description: End state: butter that has been creamed or whipped into a smooth, pale yellow paste. It is soft, spreadable, and cohesive with a glossy surface; no lumps or separation of fat. If briefly overmixed, it may be airy with fine bubbles. The shape is a small mound or scoop, often with faint peaks. The person finished may be scraping the bowl, turning off the mixer, and transferring the whipped butter to a container, shaping it, or refrigerating it for use in a recipe.

blending_oat.progress_description: Visual cues of incomplete blending: oats still appear as dry flakes or lumps; color is mottled beige with opaque swirls; textures range from grainy to thin slurry; uneven particle sizes and visible unmixed portions cling to the bowl or spoon. Motion cues: blades or a spoon churn, pull, and lift ingredients along the sides, creating streaks and splashes. The person might be pulsing a blender, stirring with a spoon, or scraping the bowl’s sides to bring remnants into the mix.
blending_oat.finished_description: End state: a homogeneous, pourable oat liquid (oat milk) or a smooth thick slurry. Particle size is minuscule to invisible; no large chunks. Color ranges from pale beige to light cream. Consistency is milk-like, silky, or slightly viscous depending on water ratio. Surface is smooth and uniform; if not strained, faint specks may linger. The person finished might be pouring the blend into a bottle, straining/filtering, and then rinsing the blender or preparing for storage.

blending_sugar.progress_description: Start and intermediate states show granulated sugar as discrete crystals of varying size and shape, predominantly white. Some grains may look slightly translucent if damp. Moisture creates small clumps or irregular lumps, and the surface can appear gritty. Crystals cling to the spoon and bowl walls, and a dusty haze may linger above the container. The person is actively mixing—stirring with a spoon or whisk, scraping the sides, and gently tapping to break up clusters, while watching for dispersion of particles.
blending_sugar.finished_description: End state: a uniform, homogeneous sugar blend with consistent particle size and shape. In granulated sugar this means small, irregular crystals of similar size; in powdered sugar, fine micro-particles. Color is white to pale off-white; no visible lumps or color variation. Consistency is free-flowing and non-caking, often with a light anti-caking coating and evenly distributed moisture. The operator finished with the task is likely sampling for QC, transferring to packaging, or cleaning/servicing the mixer.

blending_milk.progress_description: Initial state: milk sits in a pitcher calm, uniform white, smooth surface, no foam. In progress: agitation creates circular eddies and streams; droplets mix toward the center; wisps of foam form along the rim. Bubbles rise and pop; surface becomes irregular with micro-foam and a slight sheen. Color stays near-white, though aeration may tint it. The person uses a whisk, immersion blender, or steady swirling—pulses or continuous motion—creating turbulence at the sides and center, not yet a uniform liquid.
blending_milk.finished_description: End state: A homogeneous, opaque white liquid with a fine microfoam on the surface. No lumps or separation; color remains white to pale beige. It is pourable and creamy, with viscosity close to milk, and a light sheen from aeration. In a cup or pitcher it conforms to the container’s shape; no distinct layering. Brief blending yields a smooth surface with tiny foam; longer blending yields more foam throughout. The person finished with this task is likely pouring, tasting, or cleaning the blender and workstation.

blending_ice.progress_description: Start: whole ice cubes, clear or frosted, glossy and evenly sized in the blender. Early progress: cubes crack and chip; jagged shards appear; interior pockets cloud; frost forms, and meltwater beads on surfaces. Midway: a mix of sizes—from chunky fragments to coarse granules—some pieces still distinct, others broken into grit; a wet film slicks the base. The operator pulses or adjusts speed, scrapes the sides, and gradually adds ice, watching texture evolve.
blending_ice.finished_description: End state: ice is crushed into irregular granules and small shards, mostly 1–3 mm, forming a soft, wet slush. Color is translucent white with a bluish tint; surface is glossy and damp; some larger fragments may remain but no solid chunks. Texture ranges from crumbly to paste-like, often evenly distributed as a slushy melt. The person finishing the task is likely pouring or scooping the crushed ice into a cup or transferring it to a serving dish, then wiping the blender and cleaning the area.

blending_onion.progress_description: During the start or middle of blending onions, the mix shows irregular fragments of onion: large wedges, thin slices, and minced pieces, with jagged edges and peeled skins visible. Colors range from white to pale yellow or purple, with translucent onion juice pooling around chunks. The texture varies from crisp, dry pieces to moist, partially crushed pulp; some layers remain intact while other bits are already broken. The person is likely pulsing or running the blender, scraping the sides, and occasionally stopping to add pieces or adjust speed.
blending_onion.finished_description: End state: a uniform onion purée—no visible chunks or fibrous strands. Color ranges from pale white to light yellow; texture is silky, smooth, and slightly viscous with a glossy surface. Usually in a blender or processor jar, with a little liquid at the bottom. After finishing, the worker may scrape the sides, transfer to a bowl or container, and begin cleaning the blender and workstation.

blending_date.progress_description: Start and mid-stage: whole dates or large clumps cling together, skins intact, seeds if unpitted visible. At first, the mixture feels tacky and sticky, with dark brown surfaces and a few glossy globs on the blade. As blending progresses, pieces break into quarters or smaller, fibers loosen, and a coarse, tan slurry forms; some chunks remain, and the mix sticks to walls and blades. The pace might pause as the operator scrapes the sides, adjusts speed, and occasionally adds a splash of water or oil to aid emulsification.
blending_date.finished_description: End state: a smooth, uniform date puree—no whole dates or large chunks; an amorphous, cohesive mass filling the container. Color ranges from light to dark amber-brown, depending on variety; surface is glossy, with medium-to-high viscosity, and the texture is consistent throughout (no particulate; minimal froth). The mixture may cling to the sides slightly, indicating cohesiveness. The person finished might be unloading the blender, scraping and transferring the paste to a storage container, and/or cleaning the equipment for the next step.

blending_cashew.progress_description: Start/intermediate states: Cashews appear as whole halves or large fragments (0.5–2 cm), soaked or dry, pale beige to ivory, hard and dry. During blending, they break into coarse meal with irregular chunks; color lightens unevenly; texture is gritty, not cohesive, with matte surfaces. Mid-task may show small lumps and paste pockets and occasional oil sheen. The operator pulses or blends at low–mid speed, scrapes the jar walls, and adds water or oil in small increments, possibly adding more cashews to adjust texture.
blending_cashew.finished_description: End state: a smooth, homogeneous cashew paste or cream: uniform color from top to bottom (pale ivory to light tan), glossy surface; no grit or chunks; thick but scoopable/ pourable viscosity; forms a smooth mound on a spatula and adheres slightly to the blade. The person finished with this task is likely scraping down the blender/food processor walls, transferring the paste to a container, and cleaning up or preparing for storage; may also be tasting for texture.

blending_sauce.progress_description: Early or intermediate blending states show incomplete emulsification. The sauce may appear layered or mottled, with droplets or ribbons of oil, water, and solids. It forms irregular shapes—chunks, streaks, or a small mound pressed against the container wall. Color is patchy or striped, with pale, dark, or tinted zones; the surface may be glossy in some areas and dull in others. Consistency ranges from thin and runny to thick with clumps and visible air bubbles; edges cling to the vessel. The person stirs, whisks, pulses the blender, or scrapes the sides while adding ingredients.
blending_sauce.finished_description: End state: a smooth, homogeneous sauce with uniform color and glossy sheen; no chunks; medium-thick, pourable consistency; pours in a steady stream and forms a light ribbon when dripped; surface free of separation; minimal air bubbles present. The practitioner is likely transferring to a bottle or dish, tasting and adjusting seasonings, and/or cleaning the blender and work area.

blending_almond.progress_description: Start state: whole almonds, dry, thin skins; oblong, about 1 cm long; tan to light brown. In progress: almonds tumble in the blender; many remain intact while some crack or chip; fragments appear; color darkens slightly as oils release. Texture is mixed: chunky pieces, mid-sized shards, and fine specks. Surfaces show glossy oil on some parts and matte dryness on others; blades and container walls are visible; small crumbs cling to the sides. The processor is pulsed, and the person occasionally scrapes the sides.
blending_almond.finished_description: End state: almond paste/butter (or fine meal if pulsed briefly) in a bowl or jar. Color ranges from beige to light brown; surface is glossy or slightly matte. No whole almonds or large chunks; texture is thick and spreadable, from silky to slightly gritty depending on blending duration and skins. Particle size is minimal when fully blended; added liquids (water/oil) yield a smoother, more cohesive paste. The person finished might scrape the blender blade, transfer the paste to a jar, and/or clean the blender.

blending_cheese.progress_description: Start state: cheese exists as discrete pieces—cubes, shreds, or blocks—varying in size. Color matches type; surfaces are matte with exposed edges. In a bowl or processor, solids lie separate from any blended mass. Some fat sheen may cling to pieces. During transition, chunks soften, surfaces become glossy, and short strands or flecks appear; the mixture remains chunky, with distinct pieces in an opaque base and occasional air pockets. The worker loads pieces, selects speed, pulses, and frequently scrapes the bowl to redistribute material.
blending_cheese.finished_description: End state: a uniform, homogeneous cheese mixture—no visible chunks or fibers. Texture: smooth, creamy, and pourable to scoopable; viscosity depends on cheese but typically thick enough to hold a gentle peak. Color: consistent pale yellow, cream, or orange, depending on cheese; surface may be glossy. Shape: irregular mound in the bowl or a poured sheet/stream when transferred; particles at a negligible size (no discrete pieces). The task is complete when the blend is fully emulsified and ready for transfer. The operator may be scraping the bowl, transferring to a container, or plating/finishing the dish.

blending_mango.progress_description: Start: peeled mango chunks or halves, irregular shapes and sizes, seeds removed; flesh bright orange to amber; surface moisture and visible fibers. In progress: blades churn chunks; some pulp and still-visible chunks persist, with air pockets and uneven color. The person is chopping/peeling, loading pieces, and pulsing or stirring to push fragments toward the blades.
blending_mango.finished_description: End state: a smooth, uniform mango puree—bright orange-gold, free of seeds, skins, and chunks. Consistency is thick yet pourable, like a thick sauce or yogurt, with a glossy surface and tiny air bubbles; color is even throughout with no separation. Usually in a clean bowl or blender jar with a pour spout, sometimes in a bottle or cup. The person finished might be pouring into a serving container, tasting for texture, and then cleaning the blender or packaging the puree for storage or sale.

blending_cream.progress_description:
Shape: small dollops, ribbons, or a pliable mound on a whisk; droplets cling to the sides.
Size: uneven bits—lumps beside runny areas; air pockets forming.
Color/appearance: off-white with streaks, slight yellow cast, glossy surface with sheen.
Consistency: partial emulsification; thick and thin zones; visible separation of fat and liquid in spots.
In-progress actions: whisking in circles, folding with a spatula, scraping bowl, adjusting speed, pausing to test texture.
blending_cream.finished_description: End state of blending cream is a uniform, lump-free mixture. If emulsified (cream sauce), pale ivory, glossy, with medium viscosity; coats a spoon and holds a gentle mound without separation. If whipped, airy foam with soft to stiff peaks; volume increases, texture is light and glossy, color remains white. In either case, no curdling or fat separation. The worker may be pouring, spooning, or piping the product onto desserts; or resting/cleaning the equipment after transfer.

blending_pepper.progress_description: Start or in-progress state of blending pepper: whole peppercorns are the visual anchor—hard, spherical beads about three to five millimeters, in black, brown, or green, with ridged skins and either glossy or dull finish. As grinding proceeds, surfaces crack; chunks and irregular fragments accumulate, roughly one to four millimeters. Some fine specks and a light graininess appear, forming dusty flecks near the blade or chute. The mixture remains dry and uneven, with clumps where oils collect. The person operates a grinder or mortar and pestle, tapping, grinding, and adjusting speed or coarseness, pausing to check texture.
blending_pepper.finished_description: End state: pepper is uniformly ground, with particles mostly under 1 mm; shapes are irregular grains or particles; color black to dark gray; texture ranges from dry powder to a wet paste depending on moisture; no whole peppercorns visible; a moistened blend may show a light sheen and slight slurry, while a dry blend looks matte. The person finishing might scrape the blades, transfer the pepper to a storage jar, seal it, and clean the blender.

blending_avocado.progress_description: Start/intermediate states: Avocados halved, pitted, and scooped; chunks of green flesh in a bowl or blender. The color is bright green with pale fibrous strands. In-progress blending shows a mix of small creamy areas and larger, uneven chunks; some pieces cling to the blades or sides. The person is cutting or rough-dicing the flesh, transferring pieces to a blender or processor, using pulses, and scraping the bowl to redistribute chunks as texture gradually changes.
blending_avocado.finished_description:
End state: a homogeneous avocado puree with no visible chunks. Color is an even green (pale lime to deep olive), sometimes a slight central yellow tint. Texture is creamy, smooth, glossy, and thick but spoonable. Surface is uniform; tiny air bubbles may remain. Presentation: in a bowl or blender, as a mound or pourable blob with smoothed edges.
 

 Post-task activity: The worker may be scraping the sides, transferring the puree, or starting guacamole on toast.

blending_ginger.progress_description:
Starting and intermediate states of blending ginger:
 The ginger is a knobby root with brown skin; interior is pale yellow and fibrous. Initial pieces are irregular: slices, chunks, or grated shreds, sizes from slivers to 1–2 cm blocks; color ranges from light tan to pale yellow; surface may be dry or moist. As blending proceeds but not complete, pieces break into smaller fragments; fibers unravel; juices collect around cut surfaces and in the container. The mix is chunky and stringy rather than uniform. The operator may load chunks, press them toward the blades, or adjust speed and lid.
blending_ginger.finished_description: End state: uniform ginger paste/purée—pale orange-beige, with no large fibrous chunks; forms a loose blob rather than a defined shape. Texture is smooth to slightly grainy, depending on blade and moisture; consistency ranges from thick sauce to soft paste, scoopable with a spoon. Color remains consistent, often glossy from natural moisture, with tiny, evenly distributed particles if not fully pulverized. In the shot, the blender jar may be emptied into a bowl; the person is scraping the sides with a spatula, transferring to a jar, or cleaning the equipment.

blending_coconut.progress_description:
Start: coconut flesh off-white, dry, fibrous; irregular chunks 0.5–2 cm; white shavings scattered in a bowl or on a cutting board.
Early blend: pieces still large; texture chunky; color ivory; moisture minimal; edges ragged.
Mid blend: blender blades churn; slurry forms; pale cloudy liquid with suspended fibers; occasional lumps; surface has light foam.
Actions: person pulses, stirs with spatula, pushes down solids, adds small amounts of water, monitors texture.
blending_coconut.finished_description:
End state: A homogeneous, creamy coconut product—opaque white to pale beige; texture smooth and pourable to thick; no large chunks, only fine specks or fibers; surface glossy inside a clean blender jar or strained into a bowl. 
Post-task activity: They are pouring or ladling into a measuring cup or storage bottle, possibly straining if needed, then rinsing/cleaning the blender, scraping the blades, and wiping the workspace.

roasting_pepper.progress_description: Start/intermediate state of roasting pepper (in progress): Whole peppers or halved, stems attached; shapes range from bell-like to elongated; sizes vary from small to large. Skin is smooth and glossy when fresh; color ranges from green to red, yellow, or orange depending on variety. In progress, peppers display firmness with slight give, and surface heat shows as mild dulling, shallow wrinkles, and tiny specks where heat is concentrated. They may be placed on a grill or flame; the cook uses tongs to rotate, move, or prop open slits, and may cut or seed portions to aid even heating.
roasting_pepper.finished_description: End state: peppers show blistered, charred skin with wrinkled, slightly collapsed exterior; shape irregular and shrunken; color shifts from green toward red/orange/yellow with smoky char patches; flesh is soft and pliable, moisture reduced; interior membranes and seeds removed if peeled. They are cool and ready to be peeled or chopped. The person finished may be peeling skins, removing seeds, and cutting into strips or dice, then packaging or placing in a bowl for immediate use or storage.

roasting_peanut.progress_description: Start: raw peanuts are pale beige, smooth, uniform shape; intact skins or shells. As roasting begins, they lie in a single layer or are lightly stirred. Intermediate states show subtle color variation, edges darkening, and surface wrinkles as moisture evaporates. The kernels feel drier, slightly oily on the surface, and aroma grows nutty. The person is spreading the nuts evenly, turning or shaking the pan, and watching color changes, adjusting heat and time.
roasting_peanut.finished_description: End state: roasted peanuts are uniform and crisp. Shells (in-shell) are dry brown; kernels are oval/kidney-shaped, 0.5–1 cm long, golden to medium brown; surface slightly wrinkled with a light oil sheen; texture is crunchy; skins may be intact or loose; aroma is toasty; moisture is minimal; no burnt areas. The worker finished with this task would cool on racks, remove any over-roasted pieces, and proceed to sort, weigh, and package or label the batches.

roasting_garlic.progress_description: Whole garlic heads with papery skin intact; cloves white to ivory and firm. As roasting begins, skins loosen and may blister; cloves soften, swell slightly, and become translucent or glossy from oil; surfaces may wrinkle with heat. Color shifts from white toward pale yellow, but no deep browning yet. In-progress setups include whole, foil-wrapped heads or peeled cloves spread on a sheet with olive oil. The person might be separating cloves, brushing with oil, laying them out, covering with foil, or adjusting position and timer mid-roast.
roasting_garlic.finished_description: End state: a roasted garlic bulb yields soft, plump, rounded, slightly swollen cloves that surrender to pressure; skins are papery and sometimes charred. Color ranges from pale ivory to deep golden amber; surfaces look glossy and buttery. Texture is creamy, spreadable, or jam-like when mashed, with a sweet, nutty aroma. What they may be doing next: squeezing the cloves from their skins, mashing into a paste, or whisking into sauces or spreads.

roasting_tomato.progress_description:
Start: plump whole tomatoes or halved with cut sides up, smooth taut skins, bright color, firm to the touch. 
In progress: surface blistering and softening; skins pucker or split; edges darken; juices bead on the tray; uneven heating yields patchy color and oil sheen. 
The cook’s moves: toss with olive oil, salt, and pepper; arrange and space on a sheet; slide tray into the oven and rotate portions as needed while watching the texture changes.
roasting_tomato.finished_description:
End state: Tomatoes are soft and slightly collapsed; skins blistered, wrinkled, and some edges charred. Color deep red/orange with caramelized patches. Pulp tender and juicy; seeds soft with juices pooling. Size reduced by drying; surface oily. Flesh jammy and cohesive, suitable for purée.
 
The annotator would log labels, export metadata, and move on to the next shot.

roasting_eggplant.progress_description:
Start/incomplete:
 - Whole eggplant, 6–8 inches, smooth glossy purple skin; firm, heavy. 
 - If cut, rounds or halves show pale, spongy flesh with small seeds and surface moisture.

 In progress:
 - On sheet/pan with oil, pieces glisten; hiss and steam rise.
 - Skin may blister or pucker; edges soften; skin color dulls slightly as heat begins.

 What the worker is doing:
 - Washing, patting dry, slicing, salting to draw moisture, oiling, arranging, turning, and monitoring heat.
roasting_eggplant.finished_description: End state of roasted eggplant: skin blistered and charred in patches, often blackened; flesh soft, creamy, and pale cream to light tan; interior nearly uniform with fine seeds; exterior may be wrinkled and shrunken from moisture loss; overall size reduced slightly. The surface may be glossy from expelled juices. If peeled, the flesh is smooth and unblemished. A finished task might show the cook scooping out the flesh, draining excess liquid, mashing or blending for dip/puree, or transferring to a bowl for further prep.

roasting_potato.progress_description: Start to mid-roasting state: whole potatoes or cut pieces (wedges, cubes, slices) of varied size and shape. Skins intact or peeled. Surfaces pale to creamy, sometimes translucent with visible moisture; oil or fat glaze may sheen the skin. Texture ranges from firm to soft as starch begins to soften. Edges may show slight color change on exposed faces. In progress: trays in oven, pieces spaced on sheet, occasional stirring or turning, seasoning granules or oil being applied, steam rising and fragrance detectable.
roasting_potato.finished_description: End state: potato pieces are golden-brown with a crisp, crackly exterior and caramelized edges; skins (if present) are crisp, not burned. Inside, the flesh is tender and fluffy, evenly heated with minimal moisture. Size and shape (wedges, halves, or cubes) remain intact, with uniform browning and a light oil glaze. The overall color ranges from warm golden to amber-brown. The task is complete when there is no soft, undercooked center. The cook may be removing from the oven, plating, garnishing, and serving, or letting them rest briefly.

roasting_coconut.progress_description: In start-to-middle roasting, coconut pieces retain their basic form—chunks, chips, or meat slices roughly the same size. Surfaces are pale ivory to light tan, with a slight glaze from surface moisture. Edges may curl or buckle; interior remains soft and fibrous while the outer layer tightens with heat. Texture shifts from moist to drier yet still pliable. Steam and gentle sizzling may be visible. The cook heats, turns, tosses, and spreads pieces for even exposure, monitoring time and smell.
roasting_coconut.finished_description: End state: roasted coconut is dry, crisp, and nutty, with color ranging from pale golden to deep brown and caramel edges. Shapes are irregular flakes or chips, about 1–5 mm thick with variable lengths. Texture is brittle and moisture-poor; aroma is strongly roasted-nut. If whole kernels were roasted, meat is opaque and slightly shriveled; shells darkened. Post-task: cooling on racks, sorting by color/size, bagging or weighing, labeling, and cleanup.

roasting_onion.progress_description: Start: whole onions with dry, papery skin; shape round to slightly flattened; size around 4–7 cm bulb diameter; surface firm, skin intact; color varies by cultivar (white, yellow, red); interior dense and crisp. In progress: peeled and trimmed, or cut into halves, wedges, or rings; pieces laid in a single layer on a sheet pan or roasting dish; surfaces glisten with oil; edges show early translucency; moisture pockets and light sizzling indicate heat transfer; some browning spots may form. The person trims, slices, oils, seasons, and monitors the roasting setup.
roasting_onion.finished_description: End state: Onions have collapsed and softened to about 60–80% of their original size; whole onions become pliable, wedges may separate. Color ranges from golden-brown to deep amber, with caramelized edges and occasional light char. Texture is tender and creamy inside, surface glossed with a syrupy glaze. Juices are released but not pooling; aroma is sweet and roasted. Completed roast: onions easily pierced and evenly browned. The worker may be cooling, peeling skins, and dicing or mashing for soup, sauce, or plating.

roasting_nut.progress_description: Start/intermediate roasting states show nuts with intact shells or skins and hulls, kernels still sealed. Shape aligns with species (almond, cashew, walnut halves); size roughly unchanged. Color shifts from raw white to pale beige; surface becomes matte to lightly glossy as oils begin to emerge. Some shells/skins show small cracks or loosened seams. Moisture remains; kernels feel firm but slightly tacky, not yet fully dry or crisp. The person roasts by stirring or flipping, spreading on a hot surface, and adjusting heat or duration while watching color and texture progress.
roasting_nut.finished_description: End state: Roasted nuts show uniform golden-brown to amber color; intact shape with slight shrinkage; surface may be lightly oily; texture crisp and dry, with a crunchy bite; interior kernels evenly roasted, minimal burn spots; shells, if present, are cracked or removed; nutty aroma. Sizes stay roughly the same; some nuts may puff slightly. For the annotator: after completing labeling, they would QA the annotations, export metadata, and move to the next batch; in production, the worker might cool, sort, and package the roasted nuts.

roasting_pumpkin.progress_description: Start/early: pumpkin cut into wedges or chunks; skin trimmed, seeds removed; pieces vary in size and shape; flesh pale orange, firm and dry to the touch; surfaces matte and fibrous. In progress: pieces on a baking sheet with oil; surfaces glisten; edges become translucent as they soften; color remains orange but may darken slightly; moisture and steam visible. A person might be tossing the pieces with tongs, spreading in a single layer, or flipping midway through to promote even exposure.
roasting_pumpkin.finished_description: End state: pumpkin pieces (halves or chunks) roasted until tender; flesh orange-to-deep amber, skin blistered or caramelized; surfaces lightly dry with a glossy glaze in places. Shape mostly intact; size similar to initial cuts. Texture ranges from fork-tender to creamy, depending on time; aroma sweet-nutty. If puréed, a smooth orange mash. After finishing: they cool briefly, scoop flesh from skins, then mash/blend, season, and portion into bowls or containers, or use in soups/pies, while prepping for serving.

roasting_almond.progress_description: Start and in-progress: Unroasted almonds are elongated ovals, about 1.5–2.5 cm long, with smooth pale beige to light tan skin and a visible hilum. The surface is mostly matte with a slight oil sheen from natural oils. As roasting begins, moisture evaporates, sheen increases, some skins loosen, and color variation appears in spots; pieces may curl or tilt. The operator stirs, flips, or spreads them on a tray, and watches for even coating and aroma development.
roasting_almond.finished_description: End state: roasted almonds are evenly browned kernels with a uniform medium-to-dark brown color, dry, crisp texture, and a slight glossy surface from natural oils. Shapes remain elongated ovals about 1–2 cm long; skins may be present or removed, with mild wrinkling or cracking from heat. Color variation is minimal, ranging from light tan to deeper brown. Fragrance is toasty but not burnt. The person finished with the task is likely cooling on a rack, then sorting for size/quality and packing or labeling.

roasting_chicken.progress_description: In progress, the whole bird (or portions) rests in a roasting pan, shape unaltered but shifted by turning. Skin remains pale to light pink, with surface moisture and rendered fat glistening; cavity may emit steam. Edges show uneven browning and slight wrinkling where heat has hit. Juices pool in the pan as the interior begins to heat. The cook is basting with pan drippings, turning the bird, checking temperature, and adjusting heat or tenting with foil.
roasting_chicken.finished_description: End state: a whole roasted chicken or bone-in pieces with golden-brown, crisp skin and a plump, intact shape. Even browning across breast, wings, and legs; surface dry-to-crisp; rendered fat visible at edges. Juices when pierced are clear or pale; meat is opaque white in the breast and fully cooked near the bone. Slight crackling skin is common. After roasting, the cook is typically resting the bird, then carving or plating.

roasting_vegetable.progress_description: Start/intermediate states: vegetables cut into uniform shapes (cubes, batons, wedges) with intact skins; sizes roughly 1–3 cm. Surfaces pale and slightly damp from washing, with a light oil sheen after tossing. On a parchment-lined sheet, pieces lie in a single layer, spaced apart, not crowded. In progress, the cook dries/pats dry if needed, coats with oil and seasonings, and spreads them evenly. The oven is preheated or warming; pieces are slid in and flipped or stirred midway to ensure even heat exposure, while edges begin to soften.
roasting_vegetable.finished_description: End state: vegetables are golden to deep amber, with caramelized, blistered skins and crisp edges; pieces have slightly shrunk and lie in a single layer, glistening with oil. Texture: crisp exterior, tender interior; moisture mostly evaporated, not mushy. Color varies by type but generally even browning with occasional dark tips. Post-roast, the person might remove the pan, rest or taste, then plate or toss with herbs, salt, lemon juice, or other finishing touches.

roasting_cauliflower.progress_description: In the start or during early roasting, cauliflower florets are raw-cut, with stems trimmed and crowns white to pale ivory. Sizes vary; shapes range from whole florets to broken pieces. Surfaces may be dry or slightly dewy, with a light oil sheen from coating. Pieces are spread on a parchment-lined sheet, spaced apart. Moisture may bead on cut surfaces; edges look pale and somewhat translucent. Steam can rise as heating begins. The cook is tossing or turning with tongs, re-spacing pieces, and sliding the tray in and out for even heating.
roasting_cauliflower.finished_description: End state: florets are tender inside with caramelized, crispy edges. The color ranges from pale white to sunny golden-brown, with browned tips and occasional small char. Size remains bite-sized chunks, though some florets may be slightly larger depending on prep; outer surface is crisp and dry to the touch, inner tissue tender, not mushy. Aroma is nutty, toasty. The finished dish sits on a parchment sheet or plate, with even coating of oil. The person finished may be plating, tossing with salt, lemon, or herbs, or transferring to serving dish.

roasting_carrot.progress_description: Start/intermediate states of roasting carrot: sticks straight to tapered; lengths and thickness vary; color remains bright orange with intact skin; surface matte or lightly glossy from oil; texture firm. In-progress: lined on a tray with some space; surfaces glisten with oil and seasonings; minor translucence at cut ends; gentle softening along the length; edges may curl slightly; color change is subtle, not browned. The worker slices, tosses with oil and seasonings, spreads pieces evenly, and turns or checks progress in the oven.
roasting_carrot.finished_description: End state: Carrots are fork-tender with a caramelized, slightly blistered surface. Color ranges from bright orange to deep amber along browned edges; size has reduced modestly and surfaces may be wrinkled. Outer skins glisten with rendered sugars, and the center yields to gentle pressure, sometimes with a slight al dente bite. Aromatic, sweet-nutty notes predominate. The cook, finished, likely removes the tray from the oven, rests briefly, then tosses with oil and herbs or plates them for service.

roasting_hazelnut.progress_description: Start: hazelnuts are oval with smooth light-brown shells; kernels are firm and cool inside. In early progress, surfaces dry and pale beige to light tan; skins may loosen at seams and show slight wrinkling. Shapes remain rounded with minor puffing where heat penetrates. Texture shifts from glossy to dry and matte; aroma stays faint and grassy. The person spreads nuts in a single layer, stirs or shakes the tray for even heat, and monitors color and timing, without waiting for the final roast.
roasting_hazelnut.finished_description: End state: roasted hazelnuts should be evenly colored from light golden to medium amber, with a dry, slightly glossy surface from oil. Shapes are oval/teardrop, about 1–2 cm long, uniform size; texture firm with a light snap. Skins are loosened or removed; scorch is minimal. In-shell roasts show browned shells with cracked seams and exposed kernels. After roasting, the worker is cooling on racks, sorting by roast level/color, deskinning if shelled, or packing the product.

roasting_turkey.progress_description:
Start: A whole turkey in a roasting pan; skin pale and translucent; flesh pink near the bone; cavity moist; shape plump; surface cool to touch; juices pooled around. 

In progress: Exterior light tan; skin still flexible; wings tucked; legs visible; breast/meat turning opaque from center; juices bead on surface; cavity steams; pan drippings pool.

Actions by cook: Baste with pan juices, rotate the pan, check internal temperature, and tent with foil as needed.
roasting_turkey.finished_description: End state: A fully roasted turkey with a plump, oval shape. Skin golden-brown and crisp, evenly browned across breast, wings, and thighs; surface glistens with rendered fat. Meat is firm yet juicy; breast pale white with clear juices; dark meat moist. No obvious pinkness; juices run clear. Internal temperature about 165°F (74°C). Resting under foil is common. The person then carves, transfers slices to a platter, and begins cleanup.

roasting_chickpea.progress_description:
Start state: Dried chickpeas are hard, small, pale beige ovals. After soaking they plump to 1.5–2× size, with smoother, rounder profiles.  
In-progress: On the sheet they appear dry and matte; some wrinkling; color shifts to light tan with uneven patches; skins may crack; a light oil sheen may appear if coated.  
Task actions: The cook stirs or shakes the pan, rotates trays, and tests texture with tongs or a nibble to gauge progression.
roasting_chickpea.finished_description: End state: roasted chickpeas are dry-crisp and evenly browned, ranging from golden to light brown; they may be slightly shriveled with crisp, crackly surfaces and a faint sheen if oiled. Size is modestly reduced from raw; shells remain intact but may peel or split slightly. Texture is crunchy throughout with a satisfying bite; interior is dry, not chewy, with a nutty aroma. The finish often shows uniform color and occasional darker specks. When done, the person is cooling the tray on a rack, then tossing with salt/spices and transferring to a bowl or jar, or packing for storage.

roasting_corn.progress_description:
Stage 1: Start (raw): Ear with husk on; silk intact; kernels tight, smooth, pale yellow-white; husk green; surface matte.

Stage 2: Early roast: Husk loosens; kernels still firm; surface moist and slightly glossy; color pale with faint edge translucence.

Stage 3: Mid roast: Kernels plump; tiny blisters or splits as steam escapes; edges begin to curl; overall color still light.

Stage 4: Advanced mid roast: Some kernels sag from cob; moisture declines; aroma rises; surface shows more opaque patches, still light.

Action: The roaster turns with tongs, adjusts heat, and monitors for even heating.
roasting_corn.finished_description: End state of roasted corn: kernels blistered and caramelized from golden yellow to deep bronze, with occasional charred specks. Kernels are plump but slightly shriveled, tender with a slight crisp bite, often glossy where butter is applied. On the cob, rows remain intact and may show grill marks. Aroma is sweet and nutty. If peeled, kernels are evenly sized, firm to bite. The worker finished with this task is likely cooling the ears, applying butter, trimming char, or cutting kernels off for serving or dataset labeling.

roasting_asparagus.progress_description: Start/intermediate states: fresh asparagus are bright green, straight to gently curved, 4–10 mm thick, uniform length, trimmed ends, smooth semi-moist surface with a light rinse sheen; tips are closed but not softened; stalks may have a slight natural gloss and a small bend when heated. In progress: the cook washes, pats dry, trims, tosses with oil and seasonings, and lays spears in a single layer on a sheet; may flip or rotate some spears as heat begins; sheet prepped and oven warming.
roasting_asparagus.finished_description: End state: evenly roasted asparagus on a sheet pan; spears uniform in thickness and length; tips crispy and bronze-brown; stems tender with a slight bite; color bright green to olive with caramelized edges; surface glistening with oil; light blistering along the stalks; no raw, pale sections; no soggy texture. The person finished might be removing the pan from the oven, letting briefly rest, and plating or tossing with salt, pepper, and a squeeze of lemon or parmesan.

roasting_broccoli.progress_description: Start/intermediate states: florets are whole or halved crowns, 2–5 cm across, stems trimmed to uniform length. Surface is bright green, with visible moisture and a thin oil sheen. Tops are tight and upright; some florets show a slight bend at the stem. The sheet shows even spacing, with pieces not touching. In progress: florets begin to soften at the tips; stems feel more give to a light squeeze; edges may blister subtly. The cook is drizzling oil, seasoning, and tossing or turning to promote even exposure inside the oven.
roasting_broccoli.finished_description: End state: evenly roasted broccoli florets with golden-brown, caramelized edges; color ranges from green to deep olive; surface slightly dry and crisp around edges; stems softened but intact; florets remain roughly 1–2 cm, tender-crisp, not mushy; light oil sheen with occasional char. In the shot, the cook may be plating or garnishing. The annotator is likely logging metadata, labeling frames, and exporting the clip for the dataset.

roasting_squash.progress_description: During the early to intermediate roasting phase, squash is trimmed and cut into uniform wedges or cubes. Skin may remain on or be peeled; flesh is pale and opaque. Surfaces show a light oil glaze and some moisture; edges may feel slightly tacky or firm rather than soft. Seeds are removed from the centers of cut pieces. Pieces are spaced on a parchment-lined sheet or tray, ready for oven heat, with occasional seasonings sprinkled. The person is trimming, tossing to coat with oil, and placing the tray in the oven while monitoring timing.
roasting_squash.finished_description: End state: oven-roasted squash, pieces browned and caramelized on surfaces; shape maintained (halves or cubes) but flesh softened to a creamy, fork-tender texture; interior color pale orange to ivory; surface moisture reduced with a light oil gloss; skin either softened and edible or peeled off. The person finished is likely removing from oven, resting briefly, then scooping, mashing, or pureeing for serving or storage.

roasting_beet.progress_description:
Start: Whole beets are round to oblong, 1.5–3 in diameter, with taut smooth purple-red skin; greens attached; extremely firm and dense to the touch.

Early progress: Skins may blister or wrinkle; surface moisture beads; color can deepen at exposed edges; beets may shrink slightly as moisture migrates.
 
Cut pieces (if used): Exposed faces are pale purple and moist; cut surfaces show slight browning at heat-exposed edges.
 
What the worker does: washes, trims greens, peels or leaves skins on, tosses with oil/salt, lays on sheet or foil, rotates tray, and probes with a fork for initial resistance.
roasting_beet.finished_description: End state: beets are fully roasted—tender when pierced; skins loosen and peel away with light rubbing. The surface shows caramelization and a glossy glaze from oil; exterior is deep ruby-brown, interior vibrant magenta and uniformly soft with a creamy to jammy center. They may have shrunk slightly but remain whole or halved. After roasting, the person cools them, then peels as needed and slices, dices, or purées for serving or a salad.

roasting_mushroom.progress_description: Start state: whole mushrooms, caps smooth and domed, colors white to light brown, stems intact; surface dry and firm. In-progress observations: caps soften and lie flatter, edges may curl up; shrinking occurs as moisture evaporates; surface becomes slightly shiny from oil or moisture; mushrooms release liquid that pools on the sheet; some translucence in the stems; color shifts to pale or light tan, with blotches as heat progresses. Action by the worker: trim stems, cut for even size, toss with oil/seasoning, spread on a sheet, flip halfway, monitor texture and moisture.
roasting_mushroom.finished_description: End state: roasted mushrooms show golden-brown to deep amber surfaces, glossy with rendered oil; caps slightly shrunk and wrinkled, edges crisp, centers tender; color varies by piece; moisture largely evaporated with modest size reduction. Texture: crisp exterior, moist, tender interior. When finished, the annotator would see mushrooms on a tray or plate, likely being transferred to a serving dish, possibly tossed with butter or oil, and the oven may be turned off while they inspect for doneness.
